questions.text: A researcher is testing an unknown drug, referred to as compound X, and observing its effect on renal function. When she applies compound X to the cells, she finds that it enhances natriuresis, decreases serum angiotensin II concentration, and decreases aldosterone production. Which of the following is an example of this drug?
questions.solution:
The drug X used by the researcher is most likely a direct renin inhibitor such as aliskiren. These are relatively new compared to other antihypertensives. Aliskiren binds tightly to the active site of renin enzymes. This blocks angiotensinogen from binding, so angiotensin I levels fall. Since it’s newer in the medical field, it hasn’t been as extensively tested. Therefore, it is commonly used for patients who don’t respond to other antihypertensives, or it can be given in combination with other antihypertensives. In addition, aliskiren can cause GI side effects like diarrhea and abdominal pain. Other side effects include headache, dizziness, and fatigue  



Option Analysis

❌ Clonidine:
Incorrect: Clonidine is an alpha-2 receptor agonist that can be used to treat hypertension. It, however, does not act on the kidney or cause natriuresis.  
✅ Aliskiren:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Losartan:
Incorrect: Losartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker. Although it causes natriuresis and decreases aldosterone production, angiotensin II production is unaffected, as it only blocks the angiotensin II receptor.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the thick ascending loop of Henle to cause natriuresis. Loop diuretics, however, increase renin, angiotensin, and aldosterone production, secondary to the decreased blood volume.  
❌ Spironolactone:
Incorrect: Spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor blocker that induces natriuresis but does not decrease serum angiotensin II concentrations. It increases aldosterone production by blocking mineralocorticoid receptors.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy comes to the pediatrician with his parent for a well-child check. They have no specific concerns. He eats a variety of healthy foods regularly and rarely consumes high-sugar drinks. He is physically active for at least two hours per day and has good sleeping habits. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 22/min. Height is 59 inches (52nd percentile), weight is 76 lbs (16th percentile), and BMI is 15.3 kg/m2 (9th percentile). On physical examination, the child is talkative and engaging. Pulmonary and cardiovascular exams are within normal limits. The patient is Tanner stage 1. Which of the following findings would indicate the need for further evaluation?

choices.text: Heart rate of 108 beats per minute
1000 Hz is heard in the right ear at 10 dB
BMI in the 9th percentile or 15.3kg/m2 in this patient
Lack of development of secondary sex characteristics

questions.solution:
his 12-year-old boy presenting for a well-child visit should have further evaluation for a blood pressure that reads at or above 120/80 mmHg or is greater than or equal to the 90th percentile (whichever is lower). Up until the age of 13 years, blood pressure in children is evaluated based on percentiles relative to the child’s biological sex, age, and height. Any blood pressure above 120/80 mmHg is considered elevated in the pediatric population; therefore, this child’s blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg should have further evaluation.         

The well-child visit for an adolescent begins with a focused history, including discussion of any health changes since the last visit, followed by a physical examination consisting of vital signs and a full body exam, including chaperoned genitourinary and breast exams, if applicable. Important features to note are the height, weight, and body mass index, which are interpreted by percentiles based on the child’s age and biological sex. Body mass index is considered healthy when it falls between the 5th and 85th percentiles. Screening for hypertension is done by measuring a yearly blood pressure, which is also interpreted based on percentiles up until age 13. Vision and hearing are screened at regular intervals throughout the adolescent years.        

An important part of the physical examination in an adolescent is evaluation of puberty-related changes. This is done using the sexual maturity rating, or SMR, which is also called Tanner staging. SMR starts with Stage 1, which is prepubertal, and ends at Stage 5, which is complete sexual maturity. This scale consists of two independent criteria including the appearance of pubic hair in both sexes and either the increase in testicular volume in biological males or breast development in biological females. Puberty typically occurs between the ages of 8 to 13 years for females and 9 to 14 years for males. Failure to develop secondary sex characteristics by the end of these ranges should prompt further evaluation.    

Option Analysis

✅ Blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Heart rate of 108 beats per minute:
Incorrect: The normal heart rate for a 12-year-old child ranges from 60-110 beats per minute while awake. If the child is otherwise healthy, asymptomatic, and well-appearing, a heart rate of 108 would not require further evaluation.  
❌ 1000 Hz is heard in the right ear at 10 dB:
Incorrect: Normal hearing in children includes the ability to hear 1000 Hz at anywhere from zero to 20 dB. This hearing test is considered normal.  
❌ BMI in the 9th percentile or 15.3kg/m2 in this patient:
Incorrect: In children, body mass index is calculated using the same formula as adults, but the value is then charted on a graph based on the age and biological sex of the child to see where it falls relative to other children. A BMI between the 5th and 85th percentile is considered to be a healthy BMI.  
❌  Lack of development of secondary sex characteristics  :
Incorrect: The onset of puberty typically occurs between the ages of 9 and 14 years old in males. Lack of secondary sex characteristics would not yet be concerning in a 12-year-old boy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Past medical history is notable for symptomatic gallstones, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. His home medications include clonidine, atorvastatin, and multivitamins. The patient has a history of an opioid overdose in his early 30s which was reversed with naloxone. Home medications are discontinued preoperatively. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 139/75 mmHg on the morning of surgery. The surgery is uncomplicated, and blood loss is minimal. Two days later, the patient’s blood pressure was 172/88 mmHg, and pulse was 95/min. The patient endorses a moderate headache. He is alert and oriented. Strength and sensation are normal in all extremities. The skin is moist and warm. Cardiac and pulmonary exams are noncontributory. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient developed hypertension and tachycardia after abruptly discontinued clonidine therapy. He most likely has rebound hypertension. The condition arises when clonidine or another α2-receptor agonist is suddenly stopped, resulting in rebound sympathetic nervous system activity.

Patients undergoing clonidine withdrawal may also experience headaches, tremors, abdominal pain, and sweating. Treatment involves restarting the patient on the discontinued medication and gradually tapering the dose over several days.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Administer lorazepam:
Incorrect: Lorazepam is used to treat acute alcohol withdrawal. Patients can develop seizures and alcoholic hallucinosis 12-48 hours and delirium tremens 48-96 hours after their last drink. This patient has been in the hospital for at least 48 hours but has not exhibited the symptoms mentioned above and does not have a significant alcohol use history. As a result, alcohol withdrawal is unlikely to cause the patient hypertension and headaches.  
❌ Initiate methadone therapy:
Incorrect: Acute opioid withdrawal can cause symptoms ranging from sweating to diarrhea. However, most patients undergoing opioid withdrawal have blood pressures and heart rates close to their baseline values. Significant hypertension and tachycardia manifest in only a minority of patients.  
✅ Reinstitute clonidine therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order non-contrast head CT:
Incorrect: Hypertension can lead to rupture of the intracranial vessels, resulting in a hemorrhagic stroke. However, this patient has no focal neurological deficits (e.g. extremity weakness) or meningeal signs (e.g., photophobia, neck stiffness).  
❌ Obtain serum creatinine kinase levels:
Incorrect: Malignant hyperthermia can occur after administering volatile anesthetics or succinylcholine. The condition would manifest while the patient was in surgery, instead of two days later. Moreover, malignant hyperthermia would cause muscle rigidity, whereas no such finding was noted on this patient’s physical examination.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of painless vision loss in the right eye. She reports a 2-month history of difficulty dressing due to shoulder stiffness. She has also experienced right-sided headaches and jaw tightness when eating. Past medical history is significant for carotid atherosclerosis, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows tenderness to palpation on the right side of the head. Visual acuity in her right eye is 20/200, and a right afferent pupillary defect is noted. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 65 mm/h. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of shoulder stiffness, jaw claudication, and unilateral temporal headaches is now presenting with painless loss of vision, and therefore, she most likely has giant cell (temporal) arteritis (GCA).    

GCA causes inflammation of the body’s large- and medium-sized arteries, including the carotid arteries, its major branches, and the aorta. The condition can present with symptoms including headaches, jaw claudication and visual disturbances—therefore, the diagnosis of GCA should be considered in any elderly patient presenting with a new headache, abrupt visual disturbances, and/or jaw pain. Jaw claudication is a very common symptom and can be seen in over 50% of patients with temporal arteritis.  

Since temporal arteritis affects the internal carotid artery, it can affect its branches as well, including the ophthalmic artery; therefore, the most feared complication of GCA is permanent loss of vision, which commonly is painless and sudden, can be partial or complete, and can be unilateral or bilateral. Transient vision loss (amaurosis fugax) is often an early manifestation of GCA in which patients describe an abrupt partial field defect or curtain effect in the field of vision of one eye. Funduscopic examination may reveal ischemic optic neuropathy, a swollen, pale optic disc, and blurring of the margins.  

If GCA is suspected, treatment with glucocorticoids should be initiated immediately to prevent permanent loss of vision. A patient presenting with a history of suspicious vision changes should be treated with intravenous methylprednisolone. Temporal artery biopsy is the gold standard for diagnosis.




Option Analysis

❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: Ibuprofen can be used to treat acute migraine headaches in adults, which may also present with visual disturbances. However, this patient has no history of migraines, and new-onset migraine headaches are uncommon in elderly patients. Additionally, the elevated ESR and constellation of other symptoms (e.g., jaw claudication, temporal artery tenderness) suggest a different diagnosis and treatment. 
❌ Acetazolamide:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, can be used to treat idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), which may also present with headaches and transient vision loss. IIH, however, is more commonly seen in young females with obesity, and it would be unlikely to present in this elderly patient. Additionally, this patient's constellation of symptoms (e.g., jaw claudication, temporal artery tenderness) is consistent with giant cell (temporal) arteritis, which requires a different treatment. 
✅ Methylprednisolone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Sumatriptan and administration of 100% O2:
Incorrect: Cluster headaches can present with excruciating periorbital pain as well as lacrimation and rhinorrhea. Although cluster headaches may also present with visual disturbances, this patient's constellation of symptoms is more consistent with giant cell (temporal) arteritis, leading to acute vision loss. Immediate treatment with another medication is needed to prevent permanent vision loss. 
❌ High-dose aspirin and clopidogrel:
Incorrect: Amaurosis fugax (transient vision loss), as seen in this patient, can be caused by carotid atherosclerosis, where an embolus becomes dislodged and travels to the ophthalmic artery. Although this patient has a history of carotid atherosclerosis, her constellation of symptoms is more consistent with giant cell (temporal) arteritis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate lower extremity swelling. Today, his nurse noted that his left lower extremity was swollen and red compared to his right lower extremity. He resides at a nursing facility and previously had a long ICU stay following an intracerebral hemorrhage secondary to amyloid angiopathy. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, dementia, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient uses a wheelchair. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), blood pressure is 142/67 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and O<sub>2</sub> saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals an elderly male in no acute distress. The patient is only oriented to self, which is consistent with his baseline. Contractures are noted in the upper extremities bilaterally. The left lower extremity is erythematous and swollen compared to the right lower extremity. Duplex ultrasonography reveals a deep femoral vein thrombosis in the left leg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's condition?

choices.text: Placement of inferior vena cava filter

questions.solution:
This patient, with multiple chronic conditions and recent history of intracerebral hemorrhage, presents for evaluation of lower extremity swelling. He is found to have a proximal deep vein thrombosis. Given his history of a recent intracerebral hemorrhage, any form of anticoagulation is strictly contraindicated. Hence, the placement of an inferior vena cava filter is the next best step in management.

Proximal deep vein thrombosis has a high propensity towards embolization and must be treated diligently. Often, chronically ill or critically ill patients with proximal deep vein thrombosis may not receive anticoagulation due to recent surgery, known hemorrhage, or other bleeding dyscrasia. In these instances, an inferior vena cava filter may be inserted into the vena cava to barricade the heart and lungs from thromboemboli. On CT-imaging, a vena cava filter will appear as a radiodense device situated with the filter tip just at the inflow of the renal veins.


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  

Option Analysis

✅ Placement of inferior vena cava filter  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of alteplase  :
Incorrect: Alteplase is not indicated in the acute management of deep vein thrombosis. Moreover, administration of this medication could potentially incite further intracerebral hemorrhage.  
❌ IR-guided thrombectomy  :
Incorrect: IR-guided thrombectomy is indicated in the setting of massive deep vein thrombosis which entirely obstructs venous outflow from the extremity, resulting in a compartment syndrome. This rare condition is termed phlegmasia cerulea dolens, and it most commonly occurs in the lower extremities. In contrast, this patient has an uncomplicated deep vein thrombosis, and thus an IR-guided thrombectomy is not clinically indicated.  
❌ Infusion of heparin bolus  :
Incorrect: Administration of heparin would be appropriate for uncomplicated deep vein thrombosis. However, heparin administration could potentiate life-threatening intracerebral hemorrhage given this patient's history.  
❌ Administration of subcutaneous enoxaparin:
Incorrect: Like heparin, administration of enoxaparin would be appropriate for uncomplicated deep vein thrombosis. However, given this patient’s history, heparin administration could potentiate life-threatening intracerebral hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents for follow-up evaluation after a recent myocardial infarction. The patient had a high-grade occlusion of the left anterior descending artery with stent placement. The patient has been compliant with medications. However, he has pain and weakness in the left upper extremity with exercise. The patient states, “I know something is not right. My arm turns ghost white every time I get on the treadmill, and I feel like I will pass out.” Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia. Medications include aspirin, carvedilol, amlodipine, metformin, atorvastatin, and clopidogrel. He has a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 140/70 mmHg in the right arm compared with 121/65 mmHg in the left arm. The left radial pulse demonstrates arrival delay compared to the right radial pulse. The patient's left hand presents a brisk capillary refill. The patient’s cardiologist subsequently orders an ultrasound of the heart and upper extremities. Which of the following findings is most likely to be found on ultrasonographic evaluation?

choices.text: Reversal of blood flow in the left vertebral artery
Dissection flap of the proximal aorta
Deep vein thrombosis of the left subclavian vein
Thromboembolism of the left brachial artery

questions.solution:
This patient who recently underwent stent placement for acute myocardial infarction presents with signs of exertional ischemia in the left upper extremity. His findings are suspicious for subclavian steal syndrome, which will typically demonstrate flow reversal through the ipsilateral vertebral artery.   

Subclavian steal syndrome refers to a phenomenon that occurs with severe stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the ipsilateral vertebral artery – typically from underlying atherosclerotic disease. As this stenosis progresses, the pressure gradient of blood flowing through the affected subclavian artery decreases relative to the pressure gradient in the ipsilateral vertebral artery. As a result, blood flows down through the vertebral artery from the basilar vascular supply.  

Most patients are asymptomatic; however, when symptoms arise, they are typically exercise-induced. Patients can present with symptoms of ischemia to the affected upper extremity, including pain, paresthesias, pallor, and coolness to the touch. In some instances, associated neurologic symptoms may manifest, including dizziness, lightheadedness, syncope, tinnitus, or disequilibrium due to vertebrobasilar ischemia.  

Physical examination findings typically include a delayed or decreased pulse amplitude of the affected extremity and a differential brachial systolic blood pressure between the upper extremities.    

Option Analysis

✅ Reversal of blood flow in the left vertebral artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dissection flap of the proximal aorta :
Incorrect: Aortic dissection typically presents with acute, sharp, “tearing” chest pain radiating to the back. While this patient is at risk for aortic pathology given his recent cardiac catheterization, his clinical findings are inconsistent with this diagnosis. 
❌ Deep vein thrombosis of the left subclavian vein:
Incorrect: Given his recent surgical procedure, this patient is at an increased risk for deep vein thrombosis. However, a deep vein thrombosis of the upper extremity is rare and universally presents with swelling and pain of the affected upper extremity. A pulse deficit is not typically associated with this condition. 
❌ Thromboembolism of the left brachial artery:
Incorrect: An acute thromboembolism of the left brachial artery would result in signs of acute ischemia, including pain, paresthesias, pallor, poikilothermia, pulselessness, and paralysis. In contrast, this patient’s symptoms are only present with exertion and hence unlikely to be secondary to arterial thromboembolism. 
❌ Widened aortic outflow tract :
Incorrect: Thoracic aortic aneurysms are most often asymptomatic. When symptomatic, they typically present with acute onset chest pain.

questions.text:
A 36-year-old woman is being evaluated for episodes of “hand discoloration”. The patient reports that these episodes are triggered by cold temperatures and resolve after 15 minutes. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, for which she is currently taking lisinopril. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F) and blood pressure is 137/83. The patient’s symptoms are similar to those found in the image below:  



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

Physical examination is notable for skin tightening over the face and hands. Calcium deposits are present at the elbows. Initiation of which of the following medications would be most effective in managing this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has Raynaud phenomenon secondary to limited scleroderma. Raynaud phenomenon refers to the discoloration of the extremities because of exaggerated vasoconstriction in the setting of cold temperatures or emotional stress. The condition is associated with limited cutaneous systemic scleroderma.  

During episodes of Raynaud phenomenon, the distal fingers initially turn white, followed by blue, and finally, red as the blood vessels expand to get enough oxygen-rich blood to the fingers. The initial discoloration will often resolve within 20 minutes. Over time the vasospasm can cause ischemia, and individuals with the condition may develop digital ulcerations.  

Treatment involves stress management and cold avoidance. In terms of medications, calcium-channel blockers (CCB), such as oral nifedipine or amlodipine, are the first-line option. Topical nitrates and phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitors (e.g. sildenafil) can be used in patients with contraindications to CCBs or have failed prior CCB treatment.    

Option Analysis

❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: This patient’s tightened skin, calcium deposits, and Raynaud phenomenon (discoloration of the fingers in cold temperatures) are all consistent with the presentation of scleroderma. Methotrexate can be used to treat skin thickening and tightening in patients with scleroderma. However, methotrexate is not useful in treating Raynaud phenomenon.   
❌ Topical corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Topical corticosteroids can be used to treat vitiligo, which presents with depigmented patches of skin. It would be atypical for vitiligo patches to spontaneously resolve, whereas this patient’s discoloration resolves within 20 minutes.  
❌ Topical nitroglycerine cream:
Incorrect: Topical nitroglycerine is in fact used to treat Raynaud phenomenon, the condition which presents with discoloration of the extremities due to exaggerated vasoconstriction during cold temperatures or emotional stress. However, nitroglycerine is not the first-line treatment option.  
❌ Sildenafil:
Incorrect: Sildenafil can cause vasodilation. This prevents the recurrence of future episodes of Raynaud phenomenon. However, sildenafil is not the first-line treatment option. Instead, sildenafil is indicated for patients who have failed or have contraindications to taking calcium channel blockers, the first-line treatment option.  
✅ Initiation of amlodipine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of easy fatigability and pain in his legs after walking a block. The pain resolves after resting for a few minutes and is worse going downhill than uphill. The rest of the systemic review is noncontributory. Past medical history is significant for hypertension managed with lisinopril. Family history is significant for myocardial infarction in the patient’s father. He has a 35-pack-year smoking history. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows decreased popliteal and dorsalis pedis pulses and normal femoral pulses in the lower extremities bilaterally. The ankle-brachial index is 0.6 on the left and 0.75 on the right. He is initiated on low-dose aspirin, atorvastatin, and a supervised exercise program. On his three months follow-up, the patient reports minimal improvement in walking. Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Add cilostazol to the medication regimen
Computed tomography angiography followed by stenting
Add warfarin to the medication regimen
Continue the same therapy with regular follow-up

questions.solution:
This patient’s clinical presentation with intermittent leg pain on exertion (claudication), in combination with decreased pulses in lower extremities and ankle-brachial index of ≤ 0.90 bilaterally, is consistent with peripheral artery disease (PAD). PAD is a coronary disease risk equivalent and requires aggressive risk factor management with smoking cessation, aspirin, lipid-lowering therapy, and a supervised exercise program. Patients who fail to improve require additional pharmacotherapy with cilostazol.

Cilostazol is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor (another example is dipyridamole) that suppresses the degradation of cyclic AMP (cAMP) in platelets. Increased concentrations of cAMP subsequently lead to increased concentrations of the active form of protein kinase A (PKA), which is directly related to the inhibition of platelet aggregation. It is also a direct arterial vasodilator (increased cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells), but its mechanism in improving walking distance among patients with PAD is unknown. It is mainly indicated in managing PAD, coronary artery disease (CAD), and the secondary prevention of ischemic stroke and transient ischemic attack (TIA) combined with aspirin. Dipyridamole is also used in cardiac stress testing. Common side effects include dizziness, headaches, palpitations, and gastrointestinal disturbance.  

Option Analysis

✅ Add cilostazol to the medication regimen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Computed tomography angiography followed by stenting:
Incorrect: Percutaneous revascularization via stenting is indicated in patients with PAD fails to improve or show satisfactory response with a year of exercise therapy, and adjunctive pharmacotherapy. It should not be pursued in this patient without a trial of cilostazol.  
❌ Add warfarin to the medication regimen:
Incorrect: Warfarin is an anticoagulant and is not shown to improve symptoms of intermittent claudication. It is not recommended for this patient.  
❌ Continue the same therapy with regular follow-up:
Incorrect: This patient has failed to improve with exercise therapy and secondary prevention of adverse cardiovascular events. A step-up therapy with cilostazol is indicated in such patients.  
❌ Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy:
Incorrect: Catheter-directed thrombolytic therapy is usually indicated in individuals with acute deep vein thrombosis associated with severe symptomatic swelling or extensive thrombosis of the proximal or iliofemoral vein. It has no role in the management of PAD.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider because of intermittent discoloration and pain in her hands. The patient reports that these episodes occur when she goes outside during the winter. The discoloration self-resolves within 30-minutes after the patient returns indoors. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is notable for coronary artery disease in her father. In the office, her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 112/69 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Examination of the hands reveals no discolorations or deformities. Which of the following medications will be most useful in treating this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has intermittent episodes of hand discoloration and pain that are triggered by cold temperatures and improve with rewarming, which is consistent with Raynaud phenomenon. The condition is caused by an exaggerated vasoconstrictive response by the digital blood vessels. Calcium channel blockers (CCBs), in particular dihydropyridine CCBs, are the first-line treatment option.  

CCBs can be subdivided into dihydropyridine and non-dihydropyridine CCBs. Dihydropyridine CCBs, (e.g., amlodipine, nifedipine) act predominantly at the vascular smooth muscle. They are useful in treating hypertension, Raynaud phenomenon, angina via dilation of the coronary arteries, and the prevention of cerebral vasospasms after a subarachnoid hemorrhage.  

In contrast, non-dihydropyridine CCBs (e.g., verapamil, diltiazem) act predominantly at the heart but have minor vasodilatory properties. They are useful in treating tachyarrhythmias, angina, and hypertension. Non-dihydropyridine CCBs can decrease SA node discharge rate (reduces heart rate), AV node discharge rate (terminates supraventricular tachycardia), and intracellular calcium (reduces cardiac contractility).



Option Analysis

❌ Sildenafil:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms are consistent with Raynaud phenomenon. Sildenafil can cause vasodilation and has been shown to have modest benefits in patients with Raynaud phenomenon. However, it is not the first-line treatment option. 
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB) that acts predominantly at the heart. However, it has a weaker effect on vascular smooth muscle. As a result, non-dihydropyridine CCBs are not typically used to treat Raynaud phenomenon.
✅ Nifedipine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine promotes nitric oxide release from the vascular endothelium and causes smooth muscle relaxation. The medication is used to treat hypertensive crises, congestive heart failure, and hypertensive diseases of pregnancy. However, hydralazine is not used in the treatment of Raynaud phenomenon. 
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB) that acts predominantly at the heart. However, it has a weaker effect on the smooth muscle of blood vessels. As a result, non-dihydropyridine CCBs are not typically used to treat Raynaud phenomenon.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of pain and ulcerations on his fingertips. He has a past medical history of asthma, seasonal allergies, and tobacco use disorder. He has smoked 1 pack per day for the past 30 years. He does not use alcohol or other recreational substances. He has no respiratory symptoms, hemoptysis, joint pains, oral or genital ulcers, or recent visual changes. Vitals are within normal limits. Examination reveals digital ulcers and gangrene on several fingertips. Pulses in his lower extremities are diminished, and there are multiple tender superficial nodules along the veins in his arms and legs bilaterally. Laboratory results are shown below. Angiography of the upper and lower extremities shows segmental arterial occlusions with corkscrew collaterals. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 

 Laboratory study     Result    
 Creatinine     0.8 mg/dL    
 Antinuclear antibodies (ANA)     Negative    
 Anti-myeloperoxidase (anti-MPO) antibodies     Negative    
 Antiproteinase-3 antibodies     Negative    
 Anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies     Negative
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation, including digital ulcers and gangrene, superficial thrombophlebitis, and significant smoking history along with his angiographic findings is highly suggestive of thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO; also referred to as Buerger disease).        

TAO primarily affects young, male smokers and involves segmental inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries and veins of the upper and lower extremities, leading to vascular occlusion and ischemia. Vascular imaging may be helpful but is not necessary for diagnosis. Findings suggestive of TAO include segmental occlusion and corkscrew collaterals on angiography. While a biopsy can confirm the diagnosis, it is rarely needed if clinical criteria are met. These criteria include age under 50 years, current or recent tobacco use, objective findings of distal extremity ischemia, typical arteriography findings, and exclusion of other potential diagnoses. The cornerstone of management is smoking cessation to reduce symptoms and prevent major amputations.   

Option Analysis

❌ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Patients with granulomatosis with polyangiitis typically present with upper respiratory tract symptoms, renal involvement, and positive PR3-ANCA. They typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans.
❌ Behçet disease:
Incorrect: Behçet disease is characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and a positive pathergy test. They typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans. 
❌ Giant cell arteritis:
Incorrect: Giant cell arteritis (GCA) usually affects older adults and presents with symptoms including headache, jaw claudication, and visual disturbances. It is often associated with polymyalgia rheumatic with shoulder and hip involvement. Patients with GCA typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans. 
✅  Thromboangiitis obliterans:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis is a vasculitis associated with asthma, allergic rhinitis, and eosinophilia. Patients typically do not have evidence of distal extremity ischemia and superficial thrombophlebitis, which is indicative of thromboangiitis obliterans.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine visit. He is asymptomatic. He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which is controlled by metformin. The patient eats a well-balanced diet consisting of vegetables, fruits, and fish. He engages in 90 minutes of physical exercise weekly. He does not smoke. The patient’s parent has diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 65/min, blood pressure is 124/76 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 13/min. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are shown below. Hemoglobin A1c is 6.2%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Lipid panel

Total cholesterol
210 mg/dL (6.24 mmol/L)
HDL cholesterol
62 mg/dL (2.56 mmol/L)
LDL cholesterol
142 mg/dL (3.00 mmol/L)
Triglycerides
124 mg/dL (1.45 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
Diabetes mellitus significantly increases the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, and statins effectively reduce this risk by lowering LDL cholesterol. For patients with diabetes who are ≥40 years of age and have an LDL-C <190 mg/Dl, a moderate intensity statin is recommended.

All patients with LDL-C ≥190 mg/dL should be treated with high-intensity statin therapy. The American Heart Association (AHA)/American College of Cardiology (ACC) guidelines on management of cholesterol and the American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommendations include starting a moderate-intensity statin for adults aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of the calculated atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. Despite the patient's healthy lifestyle, his type 2 diabetes places him at increased risk for ASCVD and is an indication for starting moderate-intensity statin therapy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Insulin therapy:
Incorrect: Insulin therapy is typically necessary for patients with uncontrolled diabetes. However, this patient’s diabetes is currently controlled with metformin and his HgA1C is within goal.  
❌ Calculate ASCVD risk assessment score:
Incorrect: Regardless of this patient’s calculated ASCVD risk, he should be started on moderate-intensity statin therapy since he has diabetes.  
❌ Omega-3 fatty acid supplementation:
Incorrect: Initiating omega-3 fatty acid supplements can be considered for patients with lipid abnormalities. However, it is not the primary intervention for lowering LDL-C and reducing cardiovascular risk in patients with diabetes.  
✅ Moderate-intensity statin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gemfibrozil:
Incorrect: Gemfibrozil, a fibrate, is not the primary treatment for reducing LDL-C cholesterol and lowering cardiovascular risk in patients with diabetes. Gemfibrozil can pose increased risks when used with statins, particularly in patients without severe hypertriglyceridemia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of left leg pain and black discoloration of the left toes. The pain occurs with walking and resolves with rest. He first noticed a black discoloration of the toes two days ago and it has progressively worsened since then. He does not have any chest pain or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not take any medications. The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age. The patient has a 35-pack year smoking history and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.2 C (98.9 F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg. Which of the following additional clinical findings will likely be observed on further evaluation?

choices.text: Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa
Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes
Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of intermittent leg pain and black discoloration of toes in the presence of multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus), is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Further physical examination is likely to demonstrate diminished posterior tibial artery pulsations. 

Examination in patients with PAD commonly reveals diminished or absent pulses below the level of arterial stenosis as well as evidence of poor wound healing in the area(s) of poor perfusion. 

Pimenta's Point refers to an anatomical landmark to easily palpate the posterior tibial artery. This landmark is described by the midpoint on the imaginary line drawn between the bony prominences of the medial malleolus and the insertion of the Achilles tendon. Similar to posterior tibial artery pulsations, the dorsalis pedis pulse can also be decreased or absent in patients with PAD. This artery can be readily palpated lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon (or medially to the extensor digitorum longus tendon) on the dorsal surface of the foot distal to the dorsal most prominence of the navicular bone.       

Option Analysis

❌ Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa :
Incorrect: A bruit of the popliteal fossa can be seen in patients with popliteal artery aneurysms. Patients typically present with edema and pain in the popliteal fossa. The aneurysm may compress adjacent nerves leading to referred pain overlying the medial aspect of the calf, ankle, or foot.  
✅ Diminished posterior tibial pulse :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray :
Incorrect: Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray are suggestive of osteoarthritis. Osteophytic pain may not disappear following exercise and varies in intensity from day-to-day (usually worse in the morning or upon waking). 
❌ Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes :
Incorrect: Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes can be seen in compartment syndrome. Patients present with severe pain that worsens with passive stretching of the affected muscles, paresthesias, as well as sensory or motor deficits. This patient’s intermittent leg pain is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease. 
❌ Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound :
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities is used for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Patients typically present with leg swelling, pain, warmth, and erythema in the presence of significant risk factors (e.g., history of immobilization or prolonged hospitalization, recent surgery, or trauma). This patient has multiple atherosclerotic risk factors and claudication.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for a routine visit. She is asymptomatic. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension which is controlled by losartan. She has been smoking 2-3 cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 66/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Lipid panel

Total cholesterol  
236 mg/dL (6.24 mmol/L)
HDL cholesterol
92 mg/dL (2.56 mmol/L)
LDL cholesterol
122 mg/dL (3.00 mmol/L)
Triglycerides
124 mg/dL (1.45 mmol/L)

choices.text: Calculate the 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk

questions.solution:
While a general estimate of the relative risk for ASCVD in patients can be approximated by counting the number of traditional risk factors present, a more precise estimation of the absolute risk for a first ASCVD event is necessary when making treatment recommendations in patients aged 40-75 years who have no prior ASCVD and are asymptomatic. For this patient with a history of hypertension and smoking, the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) should be calculated, and based on the level of risk, prevention strategies and decisions regarding the lipid panel results can be made.

For all asymptomatic patients without a history of ASVD who are being screened for cardiovascular disease, the initial step in management involves determining the presence of one or more of the traditional risk factors (hypertension, cigarette smoking, diabetes mellitus [DM], premature family history of ASCVD, chronic kidney disease, obesity) for ASCVD. If a risk factor is present, then the 10-year risk for atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) should be calculated to classify patients into various risk categories: low risk (< 5%), borderline risk (5%‒ 7.4%), and intermediate risk (7.5%‒19.9%) and high risk (>20%). Based on this classification, optimal risk factor modification and primary prevention strategies, including statin therapy can be determined. All patients ≥ 20 years of age should have a baseline lipid profile and treatment decisions for prevention of ASCVD should be based on the results of the lipid panel, patient age, and the patient’s calculated 10-year risk for ASCVD.  

Option Analysis

❌ Initiate high-intensity statin:
Incorrect: According to the ACC/AHA guidelines, high-intensity statin therapy is indicated for primary prevention of ASCVD in patients with an LDL cholesterol level ≥ 190 mg/dL and for patients with diabetes and multiple atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk factors. This patient’s ASCVD score should be calculated before determining the necessary intervention, but this patient would likely not require high-intensity statin therapy.  
❌ Repeat lipid panel while fasting:
Incorrect: Fasting and nonfasting total cholesterol and HDL cholesterol levels have fairly similar prognostic value and association with cardiovascular outcomes. LDL levels vary slightly with and without fasting. Fasting is not generally required. It may be required with elevated triglyceride levels.  
❌ Initiate low-dose aspirin:
Incorrect: The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force advises individualized decision-making regarding low-dose aspirin therapy for adults aged 40 to 59 years with a 10-year ASCVD risk of ≥ 10% and no elevated risk of bleeding, provided they have a life expectancy of ≥ 10 years and are willing to commit to daily aspirin for a decade. Conversely, the American College of Cardiology/American Heart Association guidelines suggest limited use of aspirin in routine primary ASCVD prevention, citing a lack of overall benefit. This patient’s ASCVD score should be calculated first before deciding on treatment.  
✅ Calculate the 10-year atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Obtain an electrocardiogram (ECG):
Incorrect: The USPSTF does not recommend screening for coronary artery disease with resting ECG in asymptomatic patients at low risk, defined by the USPSTF as a 10-year cardiovascular event risk of <10%. This patient’s ASCVD score should be calculated first.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of abdominal pain and fatigue. Three days ago, he developed abdominal pain after a meal which has since become constant. He also reports frequent tripping over the right foot, unintentional weight loss of 10 pounds, night sweats, and low-grade fevers and arthralgias over the same time. He emigrated from China 10 years ago and is unsure about his childhood vaccinations. Temperature is 38 ºC (100.4 °F), heart rate is 88/min, blood pressure is 156/92 mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Erythematous nodules are present on the lower legs bilaterally. Cardiac and pulmonary examinations are normal. Abdominal exam is significant for mild diffuse tenderness without rebound and guarding. There are no joint effusions. Muscle strength with dorsiflexion of the left ankle is 3/5. Magnetic resonance angiograph (MRA) of the abdomen reveals multiple aneurysms and irregular constrictions in the larger vessels with occlusion of smaller penetrating arteries. Which of the following tests is most important to perform now?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) scan of abdomen and pelvis
Hepatitis B and C virus serologies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a combination of systemic symptoms (e.g., fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, low-grade fever), arthralgias, abdominal pain, neurological deficits (foot drop concerning for mononeuritis multiplex), renal disease with hypertension, and nodular skin lesions. MR angiogram of the abdomen showing multiple aneurysms and irregular constrictions in larger vessels with occlusion of smaller penetrating arteries suggests a diagnosis of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN). Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus serologies should be performed in all patients diagnosed with PAN to rule out secondary causes of PAN.       

PAN is a medium-vessel vasculitis that commonly involves the renal, gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal, and peripheral nervous systems. Although most cases are idiopathic, certain medications, hepatitis B and C infections, and hairy cell leukemia are important causes of secondary PAN. Identifying an underlying hepatitis B or C infection can significantly influence the management of PAN, as antiviral therapy may be necessary alongside immunosuppressive treatment to effectively control the vasculitis and prevent further organ damage.   

Option Analysis

❌ Computed tomography (CT) scan of abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: CT scan can show nonspecific abdominal wall abnormalities associated with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), but MRA has already been performed in this patient and shows the typical aneurysms in medium-sized arteries consistent with a diagnosis of PAN. 
❌ Tuberculin skin test:
Incorrect: The tuberculin skin test is used to screen for latent or active tuberculosis. polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) can rarely be associated with tuberculosis. However, this patient has no active pulmonary symptoms.  
❌ Hepatitis A virus serology:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A is not associated with polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. Hepatitis B and C infections are known secondary causes of PAN. 
✅ Hepatitis B and C virus serologies:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Complement component (C3 and C4) levels:
Incorrect: Complement levels can be useful in diagnosing certain immune complex-mediated vasculitides, but they are not specific for polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) and would not change management. PAN can be associated with hepatitis B and C and serologies should be tested in all patients diagnosed with PAN as antiviral therapies may be prescribed.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to the emergency department to evaluate severe right leg pain and swelling for three days. The symptoms have worsened to the extent that the patient cannot bear weight on her right leg. She does not have shortness of breath, chest pain, or lightheadedness. Past medical history was significant for an abdominal hysterectomy for abnormal uterine bleeding three weeks ago. The patient’s postoperative course was unremarkable. Family history is significant for hypertension in the patient’s father. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness of the right leg and ankle. Duplex ultrasonography reveals a non-compressible right femoral vein. In addition to low-molecular-weight heparin, another anti-coagulant is added to the patient’s medication regimen to achieve long-term anticoagulation. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of recent surgery (abdominal hysterectomy) and right leg pain and swelling with ultrasound doppler findings of a non-compressible femoral vein. These findings are consistent with a deep vein thrombosis (DVT). One treatment for acute DVT involves anticoagulation with heparin in combination with warfarin for ten days, followed by a three-month course of warfarin alone. Warfarin inhibits vitamin K- dependent ɣ-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Normally, vitamin K is required for the hepatic synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as protein C and S. These clotting factors are activated by the addition of carboxyl groups to glutamic acid residues within the proteins’ structure. In this process, reduced vitamin K (active) is converted to oxidized vitamin K (inactive), which is then subsequently reduced by vitamin K epoxide reductase complex 1 (VKORC1). Warfarin inhibits vitamin K- dependent ɣ-carboxylation of glutamic acid by inhibiting VKOR complex, thus depleting functional vitamin K reserves and reducing the synthesis of active clotting factors.  

Warfarin is the most commonly used oral anticoagulant worldwide. Indications for warfarin therapy include treating and preventing venous and arterial thromboembolism for conditions such as deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, atrial fibrillation, and mechanical heart valves.  



Option Analysis

❌ Binds to thrombin active site:
Incorrect: Direct thrombin inhibitors (e.g. argatroban) bind to the active site on thrombin and inactivate the circulating and clot-bound thrombin (factor II). These medications can be used for short-term (not long-term) anticoagulation in patients with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), especially in those patients with a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.   
❌ Blocks GP IIb/IIIa surface receptors:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (e.g. abciximab) work by binding directly to the IIb/IIIa receptor on the platelet surface to prevent fibrinogen from cross-linking platelets. This medication is indicated to mitigate thrombosis in patients undergoing percutaneous coronary angioplasty and those with acute coronary syndrome.  
❌ Blocks ADP receptors:
Incorrect: ADP receptor inhibitors (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor, ticlopidine) irreversibly block the ADP (P2Y12) receptor and prevent platelet aggregation. This medication is indicated in patients following percutaneous angioplasty, unstable angina, NSTEMI, and STEMI for secondary prophylaxis. It does not play a role in maintaining long-term anticoagulation for patients with deep vein thrombosis.  
✅ Blocks glutamate residue carboxylation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibits phosphodiesterase:
Incorrect: Phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitors (e.g., cilostazol, dipyridamole) inhibit platelet aggregation by  increasing cAMP in platelets and promoting vasodilation in vascular smooth muscle cells. It is indicated in managing peripheral artery disease and coronary artery disease.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of bilateral leg “heaviness and aching pain” with prolonged standing. The patient reports that the pain worsens at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and obesity. Family history is noncontributory. The patient smokes two packs daily and does not use alcohol or other recreational drugs. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the lower extremities demonstrates dilated, tortuous veins at the calves and ankles bilaterally, without surrounding erythema, edema, or ulceration. A bluish non-tender lump is noted in the right upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, that disappears with continuous, direct pressure and with lying supine. No pulsations are felt and no inguinal defect is palpated. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s groin swelling?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with lower limb varicosities, most likely due to prolonged standing and obesity, as well as a bluish-tinged, nontender, reducible groin lump suggestive of a saphena varix.   

Saphena varix is a dilated, saccular swelling of the great saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction in the groin below the inguinal ligament. They arise from incompetent valves, which permit blood flow from the deep venous system to the superficial venous system. Thus the leg of the affected side almost always has obvious varicose veins as well which are tortuous dilated segments of a vein associated with valvular incompetence. This results in venous hypertension and dilatation of the superficial venous system. Valvular incompetence of the deep and superficial veins can be determined by performing a Trendelenburg test. The affected leg is raised emptying the veins, then a tourniquet is applied to constrict only the superficial veins. The test is positive, if upon standing with the tourniquet in place for 30 seconds, the varicosities remain collapsed and when the tourniquet is removed, the internal saphenous vein rapidly fills with blood from above. This indicates that the valves of the saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction are incompetent, but the valves of the communicating veins are still intact.  



Option Analysis

❌ Femoral hernia:
Incorrect: A femoral hernia results when the abdominal viscera passes through the femoral ring. The inguinal defect can typically be palpated. This condition manifests as a tender or non-tender bulge on the upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, and can often be mistaken for a saphena varix..
❌ Femoral artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: A femoral artery aneurysm refers to dilation of the common femoral artery just below the inguinal ligament. Pain is typically absent in femoral artery aneurysms and the palpable mass is typically pulsatile. 
✅ Saphena varix:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Direct inguinal hernia:
Incorrect: Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle. This patient’s groin lump is located below the inguinal ligament.
❌ Inguinal lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Enlarged inguinal lymph nodes vary in consistency, number, presence of pain, and size depending on the pathological cause. Lymph nodes are not reducible.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of right leg pain and swelling. The patient is a business executive and returned from an overseas trip to Germany two days ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 78/min, and blood pressure is 154/82 mmHg. Physical exam reveals a swollen right calf that is 2 centimeters greater in circumference than the left calf. Dorsiflexion of the right foot elicits pain in the right calf. The patient is started on unfractionated heparin. Which of the following best describes the effects of this medication on antithrombin, factor IIa, and factor Xa activity?
questions.solution:
Heparin is a carbohydrate molecule with a pentasaccharide chain followed by a tail composed of glycosaminoglycans and is used to prevent thrombosis. Heparin can be subdivided into high molecular weight heparin (HMWH) and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

HMWH has a long glycosaminoglycan tail, whereas LMWH heparin has a much shorter tail. The length of the tail is crucial for the function of these two types of heparin. Both high and low molecular weight heparins bind to antithrombin III, a naturally occurring anticoagulant, via the pentapeptide region. This interaction activates antithrombin III and increases its activity in inhibiting factor Xa. In order to increase antithrombin III’s activity against factor IIa (also termed thrombin), factor IIa needs to bind to the long tail of heparin. As a result, only HMWH is effective in inhibiting factor IIa activity.

This patient was started on unfractionated heparin, which contains a mix of HMWH and LMWH. Hence, antithrombin III activity is increased whereas factor Xa and IIa activity is decreased. In contrast, if the patient were started on fractionated heparin, which only contains LMWH, then only antithrombin III and factor Xa activity would be affected.
 

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation   
❌ :
Incorrect: The patient is started on unfractionated heparin for treatment of deep vein thrombosis. The medication activates and increases antithrombin activity, which would reduce factor IIa and factor Xa activity.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of director thrombin inhibitors (e.g., bivalirudin, argatroban). As the name suggests, this medication class reduces factor IIa activity while not affecting antithrombin or factor Xa activity.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). LMWH activates antithrombin and can reduce factor Xa activity. However, given that LMWH has a shorter glycosaminoglycan tail than unfractionated heparin, LMWH is unable to reduce factor IIa activity.
❌ :
Incorrect: Unfractionated heparin activates antithrombin, which in turn reduces factor IIa and Xa activity.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left leg pain and swelling. The patient denies recent trauma or insect bites. He works as a long-distance truck driver. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia, for which he takes propranolol and atorvastatin. The patient’s temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 78/min, blood pressure is 154/82 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical exam reveals a swollen and erythematous left calf. Dorsiflexion of the left foot elicits calf pain. Dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses are palpated in both lower extremities. Cardiovascular and pulmonary exams are non-contributory. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Initiation of a medication that inhibits γ-carboxylation of clotting factors
Initiation of a medication that increases antithrombin III activity
Placement of an inferior vena cava filter

questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms consistent with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He should be started on heparin, an anticoagulant that works by enhancing antithrombin III activity. Of note, antithrombin primarily reduces the activity of clotting factors IIa and Xa. However, it can also reduce the activity of factors VII, IX, XI, and XII. Heparin has a rapid onset of action and is the medication of choice in the treatment of acute DVT, prevention of postoperative DVT and pulmonary embolism, and maintenance of extracorporeal circulation during open heart surgery and renal hemodialysis.

Since heparin primarily operates on factors in the common and intrinsic pathway, a laboratory value called the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is used to measure its efficacy. The aPTT measures the speed at which blood clots via the intrinsic and common coagulation pathways. A normal aPTT is between 30-40 seconds. When a patient is on heparin, the aPTT should be between 50-90 seconds.

Side effects of heparin include increased risk of bleeding, osteoporosis, and heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (decreased platelet count following heparin exposure).
 

Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of a medication that inhibits γ-carboxylation of clotting factors:
Incorrect: Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits γ-carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X, as well as proteins C and S. Warfarin can cause transient protein C and S deficiency, resulting in short-term hypercoagulability. Warfarin is not typically used for the acute treatment of deep vein thrombosis.  
✅ Initiation of a medication that increases antithrombin III activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform CT pulmonary angiography:
Incorrect: CT pulmonary angiography is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing pulmonary embolism (PE). However, this patient has no symptoms of PE (e.g., tachypnea, dyspnea, chest pain, hemoptysis). As a result, no testing for PE is required.  
❌ Perform surgical thrombectomy:
Incorrect: Surgical thrombectomy can be considered in patients who fail medical anticoagulation or have large deep vein thrombosis and resultant lower extremity ischemia (e.g., phlegmasia cerulea dolens). This patient has no signs of critical limb ischemia and a trial of anticoagulants (e.g. heparin) should be attempted.  
❌ Placement of an inferior vena cava filter:
Incorrect: An inferior vena cava filter is indicated for patients with deep vein thrombosis who are at high risk of developing a pulmonary embolism or contraindications to anticoagulants (e.g. patients who have had recent intracranial bleeding or major surgery). The patient in this vignette has no conditions that would preclude him from initiating anticoagulant therapy.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of a purple rash on his buttocks and legs, intermittent colicky abdominal pain, and right ankle pain for 2 days. According to the parents, the boy had strep throat two weeks ago and began developing a purplish rash on his buttocks and legs three days ago. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 106/62 mmHg, heart rate is 101/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a palpable purpuric rash on the legs and buttocks. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Range of motion of the right ankle is limited due to pain, and there is tenderness and swelling. There is no lower extremity edema. Laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Laboratory value
Result
Hemoglobin
14 g/dL
Hematocrit
40%
Leukocyte count
9,100 /mm3
Platelet count
350,000/mm3
PTT
27 s
PT
12 s
Serum chemistry
Sodium
142 mEq/L
Potassium
4.2 mEq/L
Chloride
95 mEq/L
Creatinine
0.7 mg/dL
Urinalysis
2+ blood, no casts, no protein
questions.solution:
This 6-year-old boy presents with findings and laboratory studies consistent with IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) with mild kidney involvement (hematuria (without casts or protein), no proteinuria, normal blood pressure, normal creatinine). Because most cases of IgA vasculitis resolve on their own and this patient's kidney disease is mild, the most appropriate treatment is supportive care and monitoring.

The treatment for IgA vasculitis without kidney involvement typically includes supportive care which may include IV fluids and non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for joint and abdominal pain. Occasionally, severe joint and abdominal symptoms can be managed with oral corticosteroids.

When there is kidney involvement, treatment depends on the severity and subtype. Patients with mild kidney involvement (microscopic or macroscopic hematuria, mild (<1 g/day) or no proteinuria, and normal kidney function), can receive supportive care and monitoring. NSAIDs should not be used in patients with kidney involvement, because they can worsen kidney function. In patients with mild kidney disease, blood pressure and urinalysis should initially be checked once per week for one month, then every two weeks for two months to assess for disease progression.

Patients with marked proteinuria (>1 g/day) or impaired kidney function (elevated creatinine) during the acute episode are considered to have severe kidney disease and should be treated with immunosuppressants including intravenous glucocorticoids. They should have a kidney biopsy to help manage the disease and determine the prognosis.

Option Analysis

✅ Supportive care and monitoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor:
Incorrect: ACE inhibitors are typically reserved for treatment of patients with severe nephritis. This patient with microscopic hematuria, the absence of proteinuria, and normal serum creatinine has mild kidney disease requiring only supportive care and monitoring.
❌ Mycophenolate mofetil:
Incorrect: Mycophenolate mofetil may be used in patients with severe kidney disease who fail to respond to intravenous glucocorticoids. This patient's presentation is consistent with IgA vasculitis with mild kidney involvement, requiring only supportive care and monitoring.
❌ Rituximab:
Incorrect: Rituximab may be used in patients with severe kidney disease who fail to respond to intravenous glucocorticoids. This patient's presentation is consistent with IgA vasculitis with mild kidney involvement, requiring only supportive care and monitoring.
❌ Intravenous glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Patients with severe kidney disease may be treated with immunosuppressive medications including intravenous glucocorticoids. Patients with mild kidney involvement are treated with supportive care only.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents for evaluation of a rash and diffuse intermittent abdominal pain. She has not experienced nausea, vomiting, or blood in the stool. The patient had an upper respiratory illness two weeks ago. The patient has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 106/62 mmHg, heart rate is 99/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a palpable purpuric rash on the legs bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. There is swelling and pain with range of motion of the right knee. There is no lower extremity edema. Initial laboratory studies are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Laboratory value
Result
Hemoglobin
12 g/dL
Hematocrit
40%
Leukocyte count
10,000 /mm3
Platelet count
400,000/mm3
Creatinine
0.6 mg/dL
PTT
27 s
PT
13 s
questions.solution:
This 7-year-old patient presents with palpable purpura of the legs bilaterally, joint pain and swelling, and intermittent abdominal pain following an upper respiratory infection. Coagulation studies and platelet levels are within normal limits. These findings are consistent with IgA vasculitis or Henoch-Schönlein purpura. The diagnosis of IgA vasculitis can typically be made clinically. Additional testing should include urinalysis, urine protein, and serum creatinine to rule out kidney involvement.

When IgA vasculitis is suspected based on history and physical exam, initial diagnostic testing should include a complete blood count, comprehensive metabolic panel, and coagulation profile (PTT, PT) to rule out other coagulopathies, sepsis, other vasculitis of childhood, and leukemia. Diagnosis is typically clinical, and a skin biopsy is not required unless the presentation is atypical. Once a diagnosis is made, additional testing should include urinalysis, urine protein, and fecal occult blood testing.

IgA vasculitis is a self-limited condition that often improves after a few weeks of supportive care in the outpatient setting, however, some children may develop nephritis, which can result in kidney injury and, in rare cases, lead to kidney failure. Children with kidney disease from IgA vasculitis most commonly present with hematuria with or without red blood cell casts and with mild or no proteinuria. A minority of patients may have nephrotic-range proteinuria, elevated serum creatinine, or hypertension. Kidney biopsy is typically reserved for patients who have an uncertain diagnosis or signs of severe kidney involvement.

Option Analysis

✅ Urinalysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ No further testing is necessary:
Incorrect: Patients with a clinical diagnosis of IgA vasculitis should have an evaluation for kidney involvement with a urinalysis and basic metabolic panel.
❌ Renal biopsy:
Incorrect: Patients with a clinical diagnosis of IgA vasculitis should have an evaluation for kidney involvement with a urinalysis and basic metabolic panel. These patients should first be assessed for the presence of hematuria, urine casts, and proteinuria before further kidney evaluations are performed.
❌ Renal ultrasound:
Incorrect: Patients with a clinical diagnosis of IgA vasculitis should have an evaluation for kidney involvement with a urinalysis and basic metabolic panel. These patients should first be assessed for the presence of hematuria, urine casts, and proteinuria, before further kidney evaluation is performed.
❌ Skin biopsy:
Incorrect: Diagnosis of IgA vasculitis can be made clinically in this patient. Typically, a skin biopsy is not required unless the presentation is atypical. Once a diagnosis is made of IgA vasculitis, additional testing should include urinalysis, urine protein, and fecal occult blood testing.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the pediatrician’s office for evaluation of 5 days of fever, rhinorrhea, and a cough. He has also developed a red rash in the perineal area, and bilateral eye redness. Weight is 68th percentile, length is 54th percentile, and head circumference is 44th percentile. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), pulse is 142/min, respirations are 32/min, blood pressure is 88/42 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, there is bilateral conjunctivital erythema without discharge. The lips are red and cracked, and the tongue is erythematous (see below). There is erythema and desquamation in the perineal region. There is a single 2cm mobile left anterior cervical lymph node. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Which of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be seen given the likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Erythema of the palms and soles
Single vesicular lesion on the finger

questions.solution:
This patient presents with 5 days of fever, bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis, cracked red lips, strawberry tongue, a desquamating rash in the perineal area, and a single enlarged cervical lymph node. These findings are consistent with Kawasaki disease. Extremity changes which may consist of edema of the hands and feet and erythema of the palms and soles are included in the clinical criteria for Kawasaki disease.

A diagnosis of Kawasaki disease can be made if the patient has ≥5 days of fever along with 4 out of 5 of the following findings: bilateral conjunctival injection, oral mucous membrane changes, >1.5 cm cervical lymphadenopathy, polymorphous rash, and peripheral extremity changes. Changes to the extremities typically appear last and include edema of the dorsum of the hands and feet and diffuse erythema of the palms and soles. Patients may also have arthritis and cardiovascular findings.

In the setting of peripheral lymphadenopathy, patients often present for evaluation of a lump or mass. The location of the lump can help identify it as a lymph node, as lymph nodes are frequently palpated along the cervical chain, hairline, axilla, and inguinal canal. History in patients with lymphadenopathy may include fever, fatigue, and poor appetite.

Peripheral lymphadenopathy can be caused by malignancy, autoimmune conditions, and infections. Signs and symptoms suggestive of malignancy include nontender, firm, immobile lymph nodes; palpable supraclavicular nodes; and persistently enlarged nodes. Signs and symptoms of autoimmune conditions include joint pain, fever, rash, and nontender mobile lymph nodes.

Peripheral lymphadenopathy secondary to infection, typically presents acutely (<4 weeks) with tender and mobile Lymph nodes. A single tender lymph node is concerning for a primary lymph node infection such as lymphadenitis or cat-scratch disease. Regional lymphadenopathy is concerning for localized infection such as otitis media, cellulitis, or strep pharyngitis. Generalized lymphadenopathy is often observed in systemic infections such as HIV, Ebstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, and adenoviral infections.   

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema of the palms and soles:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Exudative pharyngitis:
Incorrect: Exudative pharyngitis is associated with strep pharyngitis and infectious mononucleosis. This patient has clinical findings consistent with Kawasaki disease. Oropharyngeal findings associated with Kawasaki disease include erythematous cracked lips, strawberry tongue, and erythema of the pharynx but without exudate. 
❌ Splenomegaly:
Incorrect: Splenomegaly is associated with various illnesses including Ebstein Barr virus (infectious mononucleosis) and malignancy. Splenomegaly is not associated with Kawasaki disease. 
❌ White lesions on the buccal mucosa:
Incorrect: White lesions on the buccal mucosa known as Koplik spots, are associated with measles, and not Kawasaki disease. 
❌ Single vesicular lesion on the finger :
Incorrect: Patients with cat scratch disease can have lymphadenopathy and typically have a lesion at the inoculation site often on the hands. However, this patient has a constellation of findings consistent with Kawasaki disease and is more likely to have erythema of the palms and soles.

questions.text: A 9-month-old girl presents to the emergency department accompanied by her parents for evaluation of a rash and fever for the past six days. Parents report the patient has been increasingly fussy over the past several days with decreased oral intake. They state the patient’s tongue appears more red than usual. They report the patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. She was born full term via normal spontaneous vaginal delivery at 39 weeks. She has been meeting appropriate developmental milestones and vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 97/52 mmHg, pulse is 142/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is comfortable and in no acute distress. Physical examination reveals a strawberry red tongue and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and c-reactive protein (CRP) levels

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple clinical features concerning for incomplete Kawasaki disease (KD), including fever for greater than five days, strawberry tongue, and a maculopapular rash. In contrast to classic KD, incomplete KD should be suspected when a fever is present for greater than or equal to five days and only 2-3 diagnostic criteria are present, as seen in this patient. For these cases, inflammatory marker levels (e.g. erythrocyte sedimentation rate and c-reactive protein) should be obtained to guide the need for further evaluation and treatment.        

Kawasaki disease is divided into classic and incomplete KD. Classic KD is diagnosed based on clinical findings, while diagnosis of incomplete KD requires echocardiogram or laboratory findings consistent with KD as seen in the table above. Although classic KD is a clinical diagnosis, lab work is usually obtained, including a complete metabolic panel (CMP), complete blood count (CBC), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), c-reactive protein (CRP), and a urinalysis. Classic KD is diagnosed based on findings including a fever for ≥ 5 days in addition to at least four of the clinical criteria. Additional, non-specific clinical findings often include diarrhea, fatigue, irritability, poor PO intake, as well as arthralgias and cough. Patients with a clear clinical diagnosis of classic KD should have an echocardiogram to assess for coronary artery aneurysms, which is a severe complication of KD.        

Infants are much more likely to present with incomplete KD, which should be suspected when a fever is present for ≥ five days and only 2-3 diagnostic criteria are present. A diagnosis of incomplete KD requires laboratory or echocardiographic evidence as detailed in the table above. Patients with suspected incomplete KD should have CRP and ESR levels checked, and if the values are > 3 mg/dL or > 40 mm/hr, then they should undergo additional lab work and an echocardiogram to make the diagnosis of incomplete KD.   

Option Analysis

✅ Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and c-reactive protein (CRP) levels:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: This patient has clinical findings suggestive of incomplete Kawasaki disease (fever for six days and 2 clinical features of Kawasaki disease). The best next step is to obtain inflammatory markers before proceeding to echocardiogram.  
❌  Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Incorrect: This patient has clinical findings suggestive of incomplete Kawasaki disease (fever for six days and two clinical features of classic Kawasaki disease). The best next step is to obtain inflammatory marker levels before proceeding with an echocardiogram. Treatment with IVIG and aspirin should not be given until the diagnosis is confirmed.  
❌ High-dose aspirin:
Incorrect: This patient has clinical findings suggestive of incomplete Kawasaki disease (fever for six days and two clinical features of classic Kawasaki disease).
