The best next step in management is to obtain inflammatory marker levels before proceeding to echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment with aspirin and IVIG should be given once a diagnosis is confirmed. 
❌ Coronary angiogram:
Incorrect: This patient has clinical findings suggestive of incomplete Kawasaki disease (fever for six days and two clinical features of classic Kawasaki disease). The best next step in management is to obtain inflammatory marker levels before proceeding to additional imaging. Coronary angiography is not typically indicated in the workup for patients with suspected classic or incomplete Kawasaki disease.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents for evaluation of a rash that developed over both legs 3 days ago. The patient has also been experiencing intermittent moderate abdominal pain that comes and goes and joint pain that comes and goes and migrates from one joint to another. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 110/62 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Palpable reddish-purple lesions approximately 5mm in diameter and appearing in clusters are seen over the legs bilaterally (as shown in the image below). There is swelling, tenderness to palpation and pain with range of motion of the of the right knee. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. The abdomen is soft, nontender and without masses. CBC and coagulation studies are within normal limits. Which of the following additional findings is most likely, given the likely underlying condition?
 

Reproduced from wikipedia

choices.text: History of lupus erythematous in a first degree relative

questions.solution:
This 8-year-old boy presents with a palpable reddish-purple rash on the legs, abdominal pain and migratory joint pain and swelling. The most likely diagnosis is IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura, or HSP). Approximately one half of cases of HSP occur in children who have recently experienced an upper respiratory infection, especially a streptococcal infection.

IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura) is the most common systemic vasculitis of childhood and typically affects the skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys. It is a vasculitis of the small blood vessels due to deposition of immunoglobulin A. IgA vasculitis is typically a self-limited condition that improves after a few weeks of supportive care in the outpatient setting. However, some children may develop nephritis, which can result in kidney injury and, in rare cases, kidney failure.

Patients who develop HSP are typically between 3-15 years old with a mean age of onset of 6-7 years old. The classic finding is a palpable reddish-purple rash that typically appears over the legs and buttocks. Patients often have migratory joint pain, colicky abdominal pain, and a history of a recent upper respiratory tract infection. The signs and symptoms typically develop over days to weeks but may vary in the order of clinical presentation. Patients may also have nausea, vomiting, and gastrointestinal bleeding. Kidney disease is more prevalent in older children, with the most common findings being hematuria with or without red blood cell casts, and mild or no proteinuria.

Option Analysis

✅ Recent upper respiratory tract infection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ History of lupus erythematous in a first degree relative:
Incorrect: A family history of autoimmune disease has not been shown to be associated with Ig A vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), which is the most likely diagnosis in this child.
❌ Bilateral Conjunctivitis:
Incorrect: Bilateral Conjunctivitis can be seen with Kawasaki disease. Keratitis and uveitis are rarely seen with IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), which is the most likely diagnosis in this child. When these are present, other autoimmune diseases should be ruled out.
❌ Swollen, erythematous, smooth tongue:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with “strawberry tongue,” which can be seen with Kawasaki disease, which is not associated with IgA vasculitis, which is the most likely diagnosis in this child.
❌ Summertime illness:
Incorrect: Most cases of IgA vasculitis occur in the fall, winter, and spring months due to the association with upper respiratory illnesses.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department accompanied by his parents for evaluation of a rash and “red eyes.” Parents state the patient’s symptoms began six days ago when the patient began complaining of a sore throat and associated chills. They report the patient has also had “swollen glands” underneath his neck. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vaccinations are up-to-date, and he has received all appropriate pediatric well-childcare. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 101/63 mmHg, pulse is 125/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is comfortable and not in acute distress. On physical exam, there is a diffuse maculopapular rash, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, cracked lips, and a red tongue. A solitary palpable mobile, nonerythematous cervical lymph node measuring approximately 2 cm is noted at the right neck. Blood work is obtained and pending. Which of the following additional clinical features is required for formal diagnosis of the most likely underlying condition?

choices.text: Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) or c-reactive protein (CRP)
Erythema of the palms and soles

questions.solution:
This patient presents with multiple clinical features concerning for Kawasaki disease (KD), including cracking of the lips, strawberry tongue, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, maculopapular rash, and unilateral cervical lymph node enlargement > 1.5 cm. To fulfill diagnostic criteria for classic KD, this patient must also have a measured fever for at least five days.        

Kawasaki disease, previously known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome, is a vasculitis of unknown etiology that affects medium-sized vessels. Kawasaki disease is the leading cause of acquired heart disease in children in developed countries and is mainly seen in children under 5. This febrile illness can result in multi-organ dysfunction; however, the presence of coronary artery lesions determines its morbidity and mortality.         

Kawasaki disease can be divided into classic and incomplete KD, and both conditions are diagnosed based on clinical and (in the case of incomplete KD) laboratory findings. Classic KD is diagnosed based on findings detailed in the chart above that include a mandatory fever for greater than or equal to five days in addition to at least four of the clinical criteria. Additional, non-specific clinical findings often include diarrhea, fatigue, irritability, poor PO intake, as well as arthralgias or cough. Infants are much more likely to present with incomplete KD, which should be suspected when a fever is present for ≥ 5 days and only 2-3 diagnostic criteria are present. Further diagnosis of incomplete KD is provided by laboratory and echocardiographic evidence.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fever for five days:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tonsillar exudates:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is suggestive of Kawasaki disease (KD). While many patients with KD will have a sore throat, tonsillar exudate is not a mandated criteria for diagnosis of this condition. A fever for more than five days is necessary to make the diagnosis. 
❌ Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) or c-reactive protein (CRP):
Incorrect: An elevated ESR or CRP level can support the diagnosis of classic Kawasaki disease or aid in making the diagnosis of incomplete Kawasaki disease. However, it is not a mandated diagnostic finding to diagnose this condition. The patient needs to have a fever for more than five days to meet diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease. 
❌ Erythema of the palms and soles:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is suggestive of Kawasaki disease (KD). Extremity changes (i.e. edema of the dorsum of the hands and feet, erythema of the palms and soles) is one of the five physical findings associated with KD. However, this patient already has four out of five physical examination findings associated with KD. The patient needs to have a fever for more than five days to meet diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease. 
❌ Coronary artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is suggestive of Kawasaki disease (KD). Although coronary artery aneurysm is associated with Kawasaki disease, it is suggestive of the diagnosis, but the diagnosis cannot be made without the presence of fever. The patient needs to have a fever for more than five days to meet diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old previously healthy boy presents to the pediatrician for evaluation of six days of fever. He was initially seen on day 3 of illness and diagnosed with a viral upper respiratory tract infection. The fever has persisted, and parents report decreased fluid intake and urine output. Initial testing was negative for COVID-19 infection. Immunizations are up to date. He is at the 75<sup>th</sup> percentile for height and 82<sup>nd</sup> percentile for weight. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 28/min, blood pressure is 95/58 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99%. On physical examination, there is bilateral conjunctival erythema without discharge. There is no rhinorrhea. Tympanic membranes appear normal bilaterally. There is mild pharyngeal erythema. Diffuse, mobile, non-tender, and non-erythematous cervical lymphadenopathy is palpated with one lymph node measuring 2 cm. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals mild tachycardia without murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation without increased work of breathing. On skin examination, there a widespread macular skin lesions on the trunk and extremities and erythema on the palms and soles. Which of the following additional findings would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Red tongue with multiple visible bumps

questions.solution:
This patient presents with six days of fever, conjunctivitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, polymorphous rash, and erythema of the hands and feet which is consistent with Kawasaki disease. Diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires fever ≥ 5 days as well as 4 out of the 5 following criteria:

  • Bilateral conjunctival injection
  • Mucous membrane changes, such as fissured lips, pharyngeal erythema, and strawberry tongue (red tongue with bumps that is the result of sloughing of most of the filiform papillae of the inflamed tongue)
  • Peripheral extremity changes including swelling of the hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, and periungual desquamation
  • Polymorphous rash
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (with at least 1 lymph node >1.5 cm). 

The etiology of a fever in a child over 2 months of age can be differentiated based on the presence or absence of symptoms of infection. There can be symptoms of localized infection, systemic infection, or symptoms that are not consistent with infection. This patient has a fever and signs and symptoms of an inflammatory vasculitis that meets criteria for Kawasaki disease.

In patients where there is fever but signs or symptoms are not consistent with infection, age, and degree of fever can be used to further differentiate the cause of fever. If the patient is 2-36 months old and has a temperature ≥39 °C (102.2 F), an occult bacterial infection should be considered first. In patients with no signs or symptoms of infection who are > 36 months of age with any degree of fever and patients 2-36 months of age with fevers between 38-39 °C, (which is the category this patient falls into) malignancy should first be considered and ruled out. Symptoms concerning leukemia include fatigue, bleeding/bruising/petechiae, and bone pain. Lymphomas are known for B symptoms which include fever, weight loss, and night sweats. Lymphoma may also be associated with dyspnea and cough.

Once malignancy is ruled out, inflammatory disorders such as Kawasaki, systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sJIA), and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) should be considered. sJIA and SLE may present with rashes, arthritis and joint swelling, and mouth sores. If no etiology is identified, a drug reaction should be ruled out.

Option Analysis

✅ Red tongue with multiple visible bumps:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Malar rash:
Incorrect: Many forms of rash (polymorphic rash) can be seen with Kawasaki disease; however, a malar rash is not typically seen. A malar rash is more specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
❌ Hepatosplenomegaly:
Incorrect: Hepatosplenomegaly is a nonspecific physical examination finding. It is not associated with Kawasaki disease, which is the most likely diagnosis.
❌ Malar rash:
Incorrect: A malar rash is associated with systemic lupus erythematosus. This patient likely has Kawasaki disease with associated skin findings which include a polymorphous rash as well as erythema and/or desquamation of the palms and soles.
❌ Tonsillar exudates:
Incorrect: Exudative pharyngitis is seen in various bacterial and viral infections such as strep pharyngitis and infectious mononucleosis. This patient has Kawasaki disease which can cause pharyngeal erythema and strawberry tongue but does not cause exudative pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the emergency department accompanied by his parents for evaluation of five days of fever and fatigue. Parents report the patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vaccinations are up-to-date and the patient has received all appropriate pediatric well-child care. Temperature is 38.4°C (101.1°F), blood pressure is 91/46 mmHg, pulse is 155/min, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable but is alert. Physical exam is significant for a diffuse maculopapular rash, bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, cracked lips, a swollen and red tongue, erythematous and enlarged tonsils, and swelling of the hands and feet bilaterally. There is a 2/6 systolic murmur heard best at left sternal border. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. Blood work and throat culture are obtained and pending. An echocardiogram is ordered, and intravenous fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Await echocardiogram findings and lab results before starting treatment

questions.solution:
This patient fulfills the diagnostic criteria for Kawasaki disease (KD) as evidenced by the presence of fever for five days and the presence of at least four of the diagnostic clinical features. Initial treatment of Kawasaki disease is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin.       

Acute management of patients with KD involves prompt recognition of the condition based on diagnostic criteria, followed by an assessment of stability. Stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation is prioritized. Patients should receive supplemental oxygen and intravenous fluids if clinically indicated.       

Kawasaki disease shock syndrome (KDSS) is defined as sustained systolic hypotension (i.e. decrease in blood pressure greater than 20 percent from baseline) or clinical signs of poor perfusion (e.g. delayed capillary refill). It can easily be confused with sepsis. It is a potentially life-threatening complication of KD and requires prompt diagnosis. Treatment involves fluid administration, vasopressor therapy, IVIG, and aspirin. Patients with KDSS are at higher risk for KD that is refractory to IVIG.   

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG):
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. Antibiotics are not indicated. Although Kawasaki disease and group A Streptococcus present similarly, this patient’s nonexudative conjunctivitis and swelling of the hands and feet make Kawasaki disease more likely. 
❌ Intravenous hydrocortisone:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease, and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. Intravenous hydrocortisone can be used to treat refractory shock in patients with Kawasaki disease shock; however, this patient is not hypotensive and does not have signs of poor perfusion.  
❌ Await echocardiogram findings and lab results before starting treatment:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease, and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. While an echocardiogram is indicated in the workup and management of Kawasaki’s disease, it should not delay treatment. 
❌ Epinephrine drip:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease, and initial treatment is intravenous immunoglobulin and high-dose aspirin. An epinephrine drip is indicated in the setting of shock that does not improve with fluid resuscitation. Although patients can have Kawasaki disease shock syndrome, this patient is not hypotensive and does not have signs of poor perfusion.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents to the emergency department accompanied by her parents for evaluation of seven days of fever. They saw the pediatrician last week who diagnosed the patient with an upper respiratory virus with associated viral conjunctivitis. Since that time, the patient developed a diffuse, red rash and a red tongue. She has been meeting appropriate developmental milestones and vaccinations are up to date. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), blood pressure is 94/55 mmHg, pulse is 142/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals a strawberry red tongue and a diffuse maculopapular rash. Bilateral non-exudative conjunctivitis and erythematous cracked lips are also noted. The patient is otherwise well-appearing and in no respiratory distress. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is 78 mm/hr and c-reactive protein (CRP) is 6 mg/dL. An echocardiogram shows a small coronary artery aneurysm. Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) is started. Which of the following additional treatments is indicated at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings, lab work, and echocardiogram findings consistent with incomplete Kawasaki disease (KD). When patients meet diagnostic criteria for classic or incomplete KD, treatment includes high-dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) and high-dose aspirin.         

Treatment of classic and incomplete KD is the same: high-dose aspirin and IVIG are given. Cardiology should be consulted on all cases of KD. Following initial treatment, patients with KD require surveillance monitoring with repeat echocardiography. Frequency of echocardiograms and treatment duration with aspirin depends on the severity of illness determined by the presence of coronary complications. A second dose of IVIG is administered if the patient is still febrile ≥ 36 hours after the initial treatment with IVIG.   

Option Analysis

✅ High-dose aspirin :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD) and should be started on high-dose aspirin in addition to IVIG. Clopidogrel is an anti-platelet agent that would only be indicated if the patient is intolerant to aspirin or in the setting of medium or large coronary arteries, in which case it would be given along with aspirin. 
❌ Prednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD). Prednisolone and glucocorticoids in general are not indicated in the management of patients with KD. Although prednisolone can be administered when there is suspicion of IVIG resistance, high-dose aspirin is started on all patients with KD immediately after diagnosis. 
❌ Plasmapheresis:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD) and should be started on high-dose aspirin. Plasmapheresis is not indicated in the acute management of patients with KD.  
❌ Second dose of IVIG:
Incorrect: This patient has Kawasaki disease (KD) and should be started on high-dose aspirin. A second dose of IVIG is indicated if the patient still has a fever ≥ 36 hours after the first dose of IVIG.

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate acute chest pain. Before obtaining a clinical history, the patient becomes unresponsive. Temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 186/92 mmHg. A chest radiograph is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of acute chest pain. Chest radiography demonstrates a widened mediastinum, which can be due to many possible etiologies. However, of the diagnoses listed, only a thoracic aortic aneurysm is causative of a widened mediastinum.  

The mediastinum is the central thoracic cavity that contains the heart, esophagus, trachea, thoracic duct, thymus, and lymph nodes of the central chest. Radiographically, this space is defined by the right heart border, ascending aorta, superior vena cava, aortic knob, descending aorta, and left heart border. A widened mediastinum is defined as greater than 6-8 cm and can be caused by several pathologies.  

Most importantly, the life-threatening etiologies of a widened mediastinum include aortic pathologies such as traumatic rupture of the aorta, aortic dissection, and thoracic aortic aneurysm. Additional etiologies of a widened mediastinum include hilar lymphadenopathy, mediastinal masses, mediastinitis, cardiac tamponade, and vascular anomalies.   

Option Analysis

✅ Thoracic aortic aneurysm  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Large cell adenocarcinoma of the lung:
Incorrect: The lung's large cell adenocarcinoma presents radiographically as a large radiopaque mass with irregular margins. It would not typically present with mediastinal widening.
❌ Massive pulmonary embolism :
Incorrect: A massive pulmonary embolism often demonstrates pulmonary venous congestion and prominence of the right heart border. It would not cause mediastinal widening. 
❌ Left ventricular aneurysm:
Incorrect: Left ventricular aneurysm may demonstrate an enlarged cardiac silhouette but would not cause widening of the mediastinum.   
❌ Esophageal rupture :
Incorrect: Esophageal rupture is most commonly caused by instrumentation, trauma, or forceful vomiting. Patients present with severe retrosternal chest pain that may increase with swallowing or deep breathing. While patients can have some widening of the mediastinum, patients also frequently have subcutaneous and mediastinal emphysema.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a high-speed motor vehicle collision. The patient was a restrained driver when he suddenly slammed into the back of a stopped truck while traveling approximately 70 miles per hour. Upon arrival at the emergency department, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale of 4 and is subsequently intubated for airway protection. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 67/30 mmHg. Physical examination shows bruising over the anterior chest wall, but no crepitus is felt on palpation. A chest X-ray is obtained and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Rotary force applied to the torso
Vertical compression force applied to the neck
Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest

questions.solution:
Traumatic rupture of the aorta is a potentially life-threatening injury, with most cases occurring due to sudden deceleration related to automobile accidents.  

Approximately 80-90% of aortic tears occur in the descending aorta at the isthmus, which is just distal to the left subclavian artery and firmly tethered by the ligamentum arteriosum. The more mobile aortic arch swings forward during deceleration, producing a shearing force or “whiplash effect” on the aorta at the isthmus. This shearing force at the isthmus results in a tear. A widened mediastinum may be visible on chest radiography. Many patients will have retrosternal or scapular pain.  

Less common sites of aortic trauma include the ascending aorta, distal descending aorta at the level of the diaphragm, and the mid-thoracic descending aorta because these areas of the aorta are more anatomically fixed and thus less subject to movement in rapid deceleration.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sudden deceleration :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Direct, blunt anterior chest trauma :
Incorrect: Blunt chest trauma may result in sternal fractures, rib fractures, and cardiac or pulmonary contusions. It is not the most common mechanism of injury associated with aortic rupture. 
❌ Rotary force applied to the torso:
Incorrect: A rotary force applied to the torso is not the most common mechanism associated with traumatic rupture of the aorta. 
❌ Vertical compression force applied to the neck:
Incorrect: A burst fracture of C1 is also known as a Jefferson fracture and is considered an unstable C-spine injury. It often occurs due to a vertical compression force applied to the neck. 
❌ Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest:
Incorrect: Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is a less common cause of the traumatic aortic rupture. Penetrating trauma to the left anterior chest is more likely to result in cardiac tamponade, pneumothorax, or perforation of the right ventricle.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate syncope and right flank pain. The patient experienced severe right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin while getting out of bed this morning. He subsequently “blacked out.” His partner found him on the ground moaning in pain and brought him to the emergency department. The patient has a remote history of kidney stones. He has not seen a physician in many years. He has been smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for fifty years. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F), blood pressure is 93/67 mmHg, pulse is 102/min, and O2 saturation is 94% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates a tachypneic male in moderate pain. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. An abdominal radiograph is shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
Which of the following best identifies the anatomic location of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
An older patient with a significant smoking history presents with unexplained syncope following severe flank pain. Abdominal radiography demonstrates calcification and ballooning of the abdominal aorta. These findings are concerning for a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture.

The vast majority of aortic aneurysms are present in the infrarenal region and are clinically defined as dilating the aorta to greater than 50% of its normal diameter. Typically, this value is 3 cm, with large aneurysms defined as those greater than 5 cm. Known risk factors include male sex, older age, significant smoking history, uncontrolled hypertension, family history, and atherosclerotic disease. These aneurysms are due to chronic arterial wall inflammation, extracellular matrix degradation, and subsequent balloon dilation.

Clinically, most abdominal aortic aneurysms are silent and present with symptoms only at the time of rupture or impending rupture. With partial or immediate rupture, most patients present with symptoms that mimic renal colic, including back or flank pain radiating to the groin. Other findings include hypotension, abdominal pain, or a pulsatile abdominal mass (however, this finding is not always present).

In symptomatic patients, diagnosis is best achieved with CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis. However, ultrasound can also quickly detect large aneurysms. Abdominal radiographs can detect calcifications and subsequent dilation of the aorta.  

Option Analysis

✅ Infrarenal aorta  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Suprarenal aorta  :
Incorrect: Abdominal aortic aneurysms almost always occur in the infrarenal aorta. Thoracic aortic aneurysms may occur proximal to the renal arteries and track inferiorly over time.  
❌ Ureteropelvic junction  :
Incorrect: Impacted renal stones may be present at the ureteropelvic junction. An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) often mimics the symptoms of renal colic. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture is more likely.  
❌ Proximal ureter  :
Incorrect: Proximal ureteral stones often present with symptoms similar to that of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic AAA with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.  
❌ Terminal Ileum  :
Incorrect: The terminal ileum is the location of intra-abdominal pathologies, including colitis and Crohn disease. In addition, acute appendicitis can cause inflammation and wall thickening of the adjacent terminal ileum. However, given this patient’s history and findings on abdominal radiography, a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture best explains his symptoms.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to evaluate syncope and chest pain. Family members found the patient passed out next to his bed this morning. Upon arousal, the patient experienced chest pain radiating to the back. He has not seen a physician in more than twenty years. He has a thirty-pack-year smoking history and consumes 4-5 beers daily. Temperature is now 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 111/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 207/99 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient subsequently undergoes a CT-angiogram of the chest, which is demonstrated below. Which of the following anatomic structures differentiates the appropriate management strategy for this patient’s clinical condition?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient had a sudden onset and sharp chest pain radiating to the back, which is concerning for an aortic dissection. CT-angiography of the chest confirms the diagnosis. Specifically, the patient is found to have a type B aortic dissection, which is defined as a dissection flap distal to the left subclavian artery.   

Aortic dissections are caused by longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media created by a dissecting column of blood. They are a potentially catastrophic vascular complication that can lead to ischemia in various organs, namely the brain and the heart. Aortic dissections are divided into two categories: Stanford type A and Stanford type B.  

Stanford type A dissection involves the ascending aorta and more commonly leads to hypotension, pericardial tamponade, stroke, and myocardial infarction (MI). The definitive management of Type A dissection is surgical repair.  

Stanford type B dissections occur distal to the left subclavian artery and involve only the descending aorta. Type B dissections can potentially progress retrograde and present with stroke-like symptoms secondary to involvement of the common carotid artery. However, retrograde progression of type B dissections is quite rare. Instead, they typically progress anterograde to compromise blood flow to the renal arteries, resulting in acute renal failure. The definitive therapy for Stanford type B dissections is blood pressure control with either beta-blockers (e.g. esmolol) or vasodilators.   

Option Analysis

✅ Left subclavian artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Left common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The left common carotid artery is not the anatomic landmark differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections. 
❌ Right common carotid artery :
Incorrect: The right common carotid artery is not the anatomic landmark differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections. 
❌ Right subclavian artery :
Incorrect: The right subclavian artery is not the anatomic landmark differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections. 
❌ Right and left coronary arteries:
Incorrect: The right and left coronary arteries are not the anatomic landmarks differentiating between type A versus type B aortic dissections.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of left leg pain for three months. The pain is characterized by a continuous cramping in the left calf that starts after walking two blocks and goes away with rest. The patient has a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Family history includes a pulmonary embolism experienced by his mother at age 55. The patient quit smoking 5 years ago. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, and left arm blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg. Left ankle blood pressure is 210/150. Physical exam shows symmetric legs without swelling, redness, or skin breakdown. Which of the following studies is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has symptoms and risk factors concerning for peripheral vascular disease (PVD). The leg pain that worsens with walking and resolves with rest is consistent with claudication, which is pain caused by ischemia when the working extremity fails to get adequate blood supply. Atherosclerotic blockages in peripheral arteries along the legs begin to cause symptoms when the vessel’s internal diameter is decreased by 70%.

When there is suspicion of peripheral artery disease (PAD), an ankle-brachial index test (ABI) is performed. ABI is the ratio of ankle systolic blood pressure to brachial systolic blood pressure. Normally, both pressures are about equal, so the ratio is between 1.0 and 1.4. In individuals with intermittent claudication (mild to moderate disease), the ABI usually lies between 0.4 and 0.9, since blood pressure in the ankle is decreased. In individuals with resting pain (severe PAD), the ABI is less than 0.4.  

 


An ABI greater than 1.4 can indicate vessel wall stiffness caused by calcification, as in this patient with an ABI of 1.5. To prevent false negatives, patients with an ABI greater than 1.4 should have a toe-brachial index (TBI) performed. In general, a TBI below 0.5 is considered diagnostic of peripheral vascular disease.  

Individuals with suspected PVD with normal or borderline ABIs (between 0.9 and 1.0) can undergo exercise testing. In this test, a baseline ABI is obtained prior to exercise, and the individual is then asked to exercise until claudication pain occurs; the ABI is then re-measured. A decrease in ABI of 15 to 20% is diagnostic for PVD. If PVD is suspected based on the ABI or TBI, the next step is to perform a lower limb Doppler ultrasound to determine the location and severity of arterial obstruction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Toe-brachial index:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Exercise ankle-brachial index:
Incorrect: Exercise ankle-brachial index (ABI) is reserved for patients with equivocal resting ABI values between 0.9 and 1.0. A decrease in exercising ABI of 15 to 20% is considered diagnostic for peripheral vascular disease.   
❌ Doppler ultrasound  :
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound employs the Doppler effect to measure the velocity of body fluids in relation to the ultrasound probe. Patients with a pathologic positive ankle-brachial index (less than 0.9) should undergo duplex ultrasonography of their leg to identify the location and extent of the stenosis.  
❌ CT angiogram:
Incorrect: CT angiogram is reserved for patients in whom ABI and Doppler ultrasound are equivocal for peripheral artery disease, and may play a role in preoperative revascularization surgery planning.  
❌ MR arteriography:
Incorrect: MR arteriography is reserved for patients in whom ABI and Doppler ultrasound are equivocal for peripheral artery disease, and may play a role in preoperative revascularization surgery planning.

questions.text:
A 76-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for a fever of unknown origin. After 24 hours, the patient's blood culture from the emergency department returns positive for Gram-positive cocci in clusters. The patient subsequently undergoes transesophageal echocardiography, which produces the image as demonstrated below. Which of the following correctly identifies the structure labeled with X?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fever of unknown origin and undergoes transesophageal echocardiography due to concern for bacteremia and endocarditis. The above image demonstrates a 4-chamber view of the heart, with the structure labeled “X” representing the mitral valve and a superior structure suspicious for vegetation.  

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is an ultrasonographic technique wherein an endoscopic transducer is advanced into the esophagus to visualize cardiac structures. TEE offers superior imaging of the heart (particularly posterior cardiac structures) compared to transthoracic echocardiography, wherein ultrasound of the anterior and lateral chest is performed. Common indications for TEE include evaluation for a potential cardiac source of an embolus, valvular endocarditis, and left atrial appendage thrombi in patients with atrial fibrillation.  

Multiple views can be obtained with TEE to help visualize the cardiac structures. Visualized structures include the ventricles, atria, mitral and tricuspid valves, atrial appendage, aortic arch, aortic leaflets, root, and pulmonary arteries and veins.  

Option Analysis

✅ Mitral valve:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Tricuspid valve:
Incorrect: On the above image, the tricuspid valve is located right and inferior to the area demarcated by the X. The tricuspid valve can be identified by first locating the right ventricle, which is smaller and has a thinner wall than the left ventricle.
❌ Aortic outlet :
Incorrect: The aortic outlet is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Aortic valve:
Incorrect: The aortic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart. 
❌ Pulmonic valve:
Incorrect: The pulmonic valve has three leaflets and is not identified in the above image, which demonstrates a four-chamber view of the heart.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department after experiencing several episodes of non-bilious and non-bloody emesis, followed by a sudden onset of intense, sharp chest pain radiating to the back. The patient drinks a pint of vodka daily and regularly uses intranasal cocaine. He reports last using cocaine this morning. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates a regurgitant murmur. ECG shows nonspecific T-wave abnormalities, and chest radiography is unremarkable. Which physical examination finding should be assessed next based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has concerning features for aortic dissection, including sudden onset, sharp chest pain radiating to the back. Aortic dissections are caused by longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media created by a dissecting column of blood, and the condition is often associated with a pulse deficit.  Patients may also have focal neurologic deficits or a new murmur. Although aortic dissection is typically visualized as a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray, a normal chest X-ray does not exclude the diagnosis.

A patient with chest pain poses a complicated diagnostic challenge given the broad differential diagnoses it encompasses, including cardiac, biliary, musculoskeletal, pulmonary, gastrointestinal and psychiatric etiologies. Several elements of a focused history and physical examination should be obtained for all adult patients presenting with chest pain. Patients should be questioned regarding the onset, quality, and radiation of the pain, in addition to associated symptoms and provoking/relieving factors; a thorough cardiopulmonary examination should also be performed.

Additionally, all patients should be assessed for red flag features of chest pain that may indicate a life-threatening diagnosis. For example, jugular venous distention and muffled heart sounds suggest pericardial tamponade. Pulmonary embolism should be suspected in patients with sudden-onset chest pain associated with dyspnea and hypoxia and risk factors for venous thromboembolism like malignancy, recent surgery, prolonged immobilization, or evidence of lower extremity swelling. Patients with a pneumothorax will often have unequal breath sounds, with decreased sounds over the involved lung. Consider esophageal rupture in patients whose chest pain developed after vomiting or retching or undergoing esophageal instrumentation like an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (or EGD). These patients may have evidence of subcutaneous emphysema over their chest wall. Only once these emergent causes of chest pain are ruled out should other causes be evaluated.


Option Analysis

✅ Bilateral radial pulses:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Jugular venous distension:
Incorrect: Jugular venous distension should be assessed in patients with concern for pericardial tamponade or volume overloaded states. This patient’s presentation suggests aortic dissection, and he should have pulses and blood pressures in both upper extremities evaluated.
❌ Lower extremity swelling:
Incorrect: Lower extremity swelling should be assessed in patients with features suggestive of pulmonary embolism. This patient's description of the pain, normal O2 saturation, and lack of thrombophilic risk factors make pulmonary embolism a less likely diagnosis compared to aortic dissection.
❌ Pulsus paradoxus:
Incorrect: Pulsus paradoxus refers to a systolic pressure drop greater than 10 mmHg during inspiration and is often found in patients with pericardial tamponade. This condition is associated with low voltage and electrical alternans ECG changes and a globular heart on radiography. While patients with aortic dissection may develop tamponade (due to dissection into the pericardium), it is usually a late complication.
❌ Palpation of the chest wall:
Incorrect: Subcutaneous emphysema is often noted in patients with Boerhaave syndrome; however, this patient has a normal chest radiograph, making Boerhaave less likely.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset sharp chest pain radiating to the back. The patient reports he has a history of long-standing hypertension, but he has not taken his medications in quite some time. His temperature is now 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination shows 1+ peripheral pulses in the right upper extremity and 2+ pulses in the left upper extremity. Neurological examination shows 3/5 power in the left upper and lower extremities compared to 5/5 power in the right upper and lower extremities. Cardiovascular examination reveals muffled heart sounds. An ECG is obtained, which shows non-specific T-wave changes as well as electrical alternans. Non-contrast CT-brain is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has concerning features for an aortic dissection including sudden onset, sharp chest pain radiating to the back, with associated findings of hypotension, pericardial tamponade, myocardial infarction, and focal neurologic deficits.  

Aortic dissections are caused by longitudinal cleavage of the aortic media created by a dissecting column of blood. They are a potentially catastrophic vascular complication that can cause end organ ischemia to a variety of organs - namely the brain and the heart. Aortic dissections are divided into two categories: Stanford type A and Stanford type B. Stanford type A dissection involves the ascending aorta and more commonly leads to hypotension, pericardial tamponade, stroke, and myocardial infarction (MI). The definitive management of Type A dissection is surgical repair.  

Stanford type B dissections occur distal to the ligamentum arteriosum and involve only the descending aorta. Type B dissections can also present with stroke-like symptoms, if for example the dissection were to progress retrograde and involve the left common carotid artery; however, this would produce right sided weakness, as opposed to left sided weakness seen in this patient. Type B dissections rarely dissect retrograde to yield tamponade, but they can progress anterograde to compromise blood flow to the renal arteries, resulting in acute renal failure. The definitive therapy for Stanford type B dissections is blood pressure control with either beta blockers, like esmolol, or vasodilators.  



Option Analysis

✅ Open vascular repair  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ IV esmolol:
Incorrect: Blood pressure management is the definitive therapy for type B aortic dissections, which occur distal to the ligamentum arteriosum and involve only the descending aorta.  The patient in this vignette has concerning features for pericardial tamponade given the muffled heart sounds and the electrical alternans on ECG. Pericardial effusions and subsequent tamponade are uncommon sequelae of type B aortic dissections and more common with type A aortic dissections.  
❌  Thrombolytic therapy  :
Incorrect: Thrombolytic therapy may be the treatment for an ischemic stroke or massive PE; however, the definitive treatment for this patient’s condition is endovascular repair of the ascending aorta. While PE is possible, the patient is this vignette is not hypoxic, and no signs of right ventricular strain are noted on his ECG, making the diagnosis of a massive PE less likely. The patient in this vignette is likely suffering a stroke from an aortic dissection; however, administration of thrombolytics in this situation may precipitate uncontrolled bleeding into the dissection and worsen the hemodynamic compromise.  
❌ Coronary revascularization:
Incorrect: While aortic dissections can mimic findings of acute MI due to compression on the coronary vessels, definitive therapy for type A aortic dissection involves endovascular repair of the ascending aorta. Patients with a true MI usually present with dull, pressure like pain, worsened on exertion, and relieved with rest or nitroglycerin. Neurologic deficits are an uncommon feature of isolated myocardial infarctions.   
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: The patient in this vignette does have exam features concerning for pericardial tamponade, including electrical alternans, muffled heart sounds, hypotension and tachycardia. While pericardiocentesis may improve this patient’s hemodynamic instability, the definitive treatment for this patient’s condition involves repair of the aorta to prevent further pericardial tamponade.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man comes to the clinic with persistent leg pain with exertion. Three months ago, the patient was found to have an ankle-brachial index of 0.6, and he was started on atorvastatin, chlorthalidone, and aspirin. Since then, the patient has successfully quit smoking and has participated in a supervised exercise therapy program where he has achieved a 10 lb (4.5 kg) weight loss. The pain, characterized by aching in the right thigh and buttock after walking more than 3 blocks, has not improved. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min and regular, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 130/75 mmHg, and BMI is 32 kg/m2. Pulses in the right femoral artery are diminished compared to the left. Which of the following therapies is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presented with claudication and an ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.6, confirming the diagnosis of moderate peripheral artery disease (PAD). He was appropriately started on lifestyle modifications (weight reduction, exercise therapy, smoking cessation) and pharmacologic astherosclerotic risk-reduction therapies (statin for cholesterol reduction, calcium channel blocker for blood pressure reduction, and antiplatelet drugs to reduce thrombotic risk) but has had no noticeable improvement in symptoms after three months.

At this point, the most appropriate next step is to start cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase type 3 (PDE3) inhibitor. By inhibiting PDE3 and thereby increasing cAMP, active protein kinase A (PKA) levels are boosted, leading to an inhibition of platelet aggregation and enhanced arterial vasodilation. If symptoms still fail to improve after an additional three months, advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography) should be performed to identify potential invasive therapeutic targets.    


A percutaneous revascularization approach called percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is the first choice for individuals with a single, short segment of blood vessel that has uniform occlusion. In this procedure, a deflated balloon is introduced into the target vessel and inflated to open the vessel and increase blood flow. In some cases, a stent is also placed. Once blood is flowing freely through the artery, the balloon catheter is taken out. This treatment is less invasive but not as durable as open surgery.  

Open surgery is reserved for occlusions that affect long, multifocal segments or contain calcified lesions. Surgical options for revascularization are endarterectomy, where the artery is opened up and plaque is removed, or bypass, where a graft is used to create a new conduit that reroutes blood around a blocked artery.  

Option Analysis

❌ Trial of a P2Y12 inhibitor  :
Incorrect: Dual antiplatelet therapy (usually a combination of aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor like clopidogrel) has not been shown to improve outcomes in patients with peripheral artery disease, and it can place the patient at unnecessary risk for severe bleeding.  
✅ Trial of a PDE3 inhibitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation below.  
❌ Aortoiliac angioplasty:
Incorrect: Aortoiliac angioplasty is reserved for patients with peripheral artery disease who fail conservative pharmacologic and lifestyle management and have significant aortoiliac disease confirmed on advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography).   
❌ Femoropopliteal angioplasty:
Incorrect: Femoropopliteal angioplasty is reserved for patients with peripheral artery disease who fail conservative pharmacologic and lifestyle management and have significant, lifestyle-limiting femoropopliteal disease confirmed on advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography).   
❌ Femoropopliteal bypass:
Incorrect: Femoropopliteal bypass is reserved for patients with peripheral artery disease who fail conservative pharmacologic and lifestyle management and have significant, lifestyle-limiting, long-segment femoropopliteal disease confirmed on advanced vascular imaging (CT or MR angiography).

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents to his primary care physician’s office for a routine physical exam. He is in his usual state of health. He has hypertension and takes amlodipine. He has sleep apnea and uses a CPAP machine nightly. He smokes ½ pack of cigarettes daily. He does not drink and smokes marijuana approximately once a month at social gatherings. He has been exposed to asbestos through his job doing construction. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. Temperature is 36.4 °C (97.5 °F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 130/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. BMI is 24 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Carotid upstroke is normal bilaterally. Abdominal examination is normal. There is no lower extremity edema. In addition to hypertension, which of the following is an indication for ultrasound evaluation for carotid artery disease?
questions.solution:
This patient is at increased risk for carotid artery disease (CAD) and should undergo a carotid duplex ultrasound. His increased risk is based on the presence of hypertension and a significant smoking history.

Atherosclerotic build-up in arterial vessels causes carotid artery disease. This build-up develops over years, therefore the prevalence of carotid artery stenosis increases with age. Patients can be asymptomatic. If stenosis becomes severe, it can lead to symptoms and complications, the most worrisome being ischemic stroke.

Society guidelines for screening asymptomatic patients for carotid artery disease differ. Screening recommendations discussed here are based on guidelines from the American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines. Screening for carotid artery disease in asymptomatic patients is based on personal and family history which helps determine the patient’s risk for carotid artery disease. Patients who are at high risk for carotid artery disease should undergo a carotid artery duplex ultrasound. Patients who have a history of atherosclerotic disease, such as peripheral arterial disease or coronary artery disease are considered high-risk for carotid artery stenosis. In addition, patients who have 2 or more of the following are also at high-risk for carotid artery stenosis: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, tobacco use, a family history of atherosclerosis diagnosed before age 60, and a family history of ischemic stroke. For patients at low risk, no screening is recommended.  

Option Analysis

✅ Smoking history:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Body mass index:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal body mass index which does not place him at increased risk for carotid artery stenosis.  
❌ Family history of cardiovascular disease:
Incorrect: History of cardiovascular disease in first-degree relatives before age 60 can help define high-risk for carotid disease. In this case, the patient’s father was 75 years old when he had cardiovascular disease.  
❌ Occasional marijuana use:
Incorrect: Occasional marijuana use has not been shown to increase risk of carotid artery disease.  
❌ Asbestos exposure:
Incorrect: Asbestos exposure has not been shown to increase risk of carotid artery disease.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man was referred to the vascular clinic for a four-month history of atraumatic leg pain and an ulcer. The patient has bilateral calf pain when doing tasks around the house. The pain is typically relieved after resting for a few minutes. An ulcer on the top of the left foot appeared 3 weeks ago. There is no associated chest pain, shortness of breath, unintentional weight loss, or fatigue. The patient’s past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, semaglutide, atorvastatin and hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.7 °F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 122/83 mmHg. Physical examination of the lower extremities reveals cool legs with little to no hair, delayed capillary refill in the toes, and diminished pulses bilaterally. There is a 1 cm ulcer with a dry base on top of the left forefoot. There is no edema in either extremity. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and hypertension presents with intermittent bilateral lower extremity claudication and a new lower extremity ulcer likely has peripheral arterial disease (PAD) with an ischemic ulcer. Auscultation of the femoral arteries may reveal bruits which signify turbulent blood flow through narrowed (i.e. stenotic) vessels.      
PAD occurs when there is impaired blood flow to the lower extremities. Claudication is a hallmark feature of PAD and refers to pain that is induced by exercise and relieved with rest.    

Risk factors for PAD include smoking, hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and chronic kidney disease. Associated physical examination findings include cool lower extremities with hair loss, absent or reduced distal pulses, abnormal capillary refill, and femoral artery bruits on auscultation.    

Option Analysis

✅ Femoral artery bruit:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stasis dermatitis:
Incorrect: Stasis dermatitis (i.e. venous eczema) is a dry skin condition associated with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI). Patients with CVI usually present with bilateral lower extremity edema, varicose veins and leg cramps. This patient’s symptoms and physical examination are more consistent with arterial insufficiency with an ulcer.   
❌ Ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 1.2:
Incorrect: A normal ABI range is between 0.9 and 1.4. An ABI of 1.2 is within the normal range and would not be expected in this patient who likely has peripheral arterial disease. An ankle-brachial index (ABI) less than 0.9 would be expected.
❌ Elevated cardiac troponins:
Incorrect: Elevated cardiac troponins are seen in cases of acute myocardial infarction (AMI). This patient’s history and presentation are not consistent with an AMI.
❌ Elevated D-dimer:
Incorrect: An elevated D-dimer can be seen with deep vein thrombosis (DVT), pulmonary embolism (PE), disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), cerebrovascular accident (CVA), myocardial infarction (MI), and certain malignancies. This patient has no evidence of unilateral leg swelling, which would be expected with DVT.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of leg pain. The patient is a retired architect and spends most of his time reading. During the past three months, the patient has experienced intermittent calf pain that occurs while he is doing chores around the house. The pain is relieved after sitting for a few minutes. There is no associated dyspnea, orthopnea, or chest pain. The patient has hyperlipidemia and hypertension that are well controlled with ezetimibe and enalapril, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 117/78 mmHg. His pre-exercise ankle-brachial index is 0.95 and post-exercise ABI is 0.65. On physical examination, the lower extremities are cool and hairless and the bilateral distal lower extremity pulses are weak. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with hyperlipidemia and hypertension presents with intermittent claudication (pain relieved with rest), weak peripheral pulses, and a post-exercise ankle-brachial index (ABI) of 0.65, which is consistent with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). In patients with PAD that is not severe (no rest pain, ulcers, necrosis, or gangrene), initial management should include a supervised graded exercise program along with risk factor modification.  

A supervised graded exercise program has been shown to improve function, reduce symptoms, and potentially delay the progression of PAD.    

Patients should be assessed for risk factors, and risk factor modification and secondary prevention of CAD should be initiated. Smoking cessation has been shown to improve blood flow and reduce the severity of PAD. Patients should be provided support, counseling, and referral to smoking cessation programs or pharmacotherapy (e.g. nicotine replacement therapy).    

Medical management to manage comorbidities, such as antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin or clopidogrel) should be offered. In patients with diabetes mellitus, HbA1c should be maintained below 7%. This patient has well-controlled hyperlipidemia and hypertension and does not need changes to his medications. However, for patients with PAD and inadequately controlled hyperlipidemia or hypertension, management with a high-intensity statin (e.g., atorvastatin) with an LDL-C goal < 70, and maintenance of blood pressure < 140/90 mmHg is recommended.    

If symptoms fail to improve following a 4-6 week trial of conservative management including graded exercise and risk factor modification, then cilostazol should be added to the treatment regimen. If there is still no improvement, then patients should be referred to surgery for assessment with angiography. Patients with PAD and ischemic ulcers should be referred to wound care or surgery, depending on the severity.  



Option Analysis

✅ Supervised graded exercise program:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergent limb amputation:
Incorrect: Emergent limb amputation should be considered in cases of severe CTLI where there is severe tissue loss, gangrene, or severely compromised blood flow to the affected limb. This patient does not have pain at rest or ulcers on the legs or feet.
❌ Surgical arterial revascularization:
Incorrect: Revascularization is used in the treatment of severe cases of PAD or critical limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) which this patient does not have, as there is no foot pain at rest, ulceration, or tissue necrosis. 
❌ Debridement :
Incorrect: Debridement is typically reserved for severe cases of necrosis. This patient does not have any lower extremity ulcers.
❌ Treatment with cilostazol:
Incorrect: Cilostazol is usually reserved for patients with PAD who fail to improve after 4-6 weeks with other treatments (e.g., exercise program, smoking cessation, antiplatelet therapy).

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with moderate pain in the right leg. About three hours ago, he developed non-radiating pain in the right calf without any associated trauma. The patient has occasionally experienced pain at night in the right calf that has been relieved by dangling the right leg off the side of the bed. Past medical history is significant for recently diagnosed colon cancer and insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus. The patient has been preoccupied with his recent diagnosis of colon cancer and has not been taking his insulin regularly. HbA1c was 10.1% two months ago. Temperature is 37.0ºC, pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/82 mmHg. A right lower extremity vascular exam is notable for non-palpable distal pulses, absent arterial doppler signals, and present venous doppler signals. The right lower extremity strength is intact but sensation is absent in the toes. A CT angiogram is ordered and pending. Which of the following is the most appropriate classification for this patient’s limb?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with acute, moderate right leg pain in the setting of chronic leg pain and poorly controlled diabetes. The new malignancy combined with likely underlying peripheral arterial disease likely created a hypercoagulable environment for a thrombosis to develop in the right leg. The physical exam is notable for absent arterial doppler signals but present venous signals, intact motor function, but absent sensation in the toes. Given the exam findings and the moderate nature of the pain, this patient likely has Rutherford Class IIa acute limb ischemia.        

Rutherford Class IIa describes a marginally threatened limb. These patients typically report moderate to severe pain and on exam have mild sensory loss without muscle weakness. Doppler arterial signals may or may not be audible, and venous signals will be audible. Treatment involves initiating an IV heparin infusion and ordering a CT angiogram (CTA) to confirm the diagnosis and assess vascular anatomy for surgical planning.        

CTA for Rutherford Class IIa would show acute arterial occlusion to the major vasculature of the affected limb, often with evidence of chronic vascular disease. The surgical team should be consulted urgently to evaluate for revascularization, usually within 6 to 24 hours.    

Option Analysis

❌ Rutherford Class I  :
Incorrect: This class is for viable limbs under no immediate threat of tissue loss. It is the mildest form of limb ischemia. With viable limbs, there would be no sensory loss or muscle weakness, and both arterial and venous Doppler signals would be audible. 
✅ Rutherford Class IIa :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rutherford Class IIb :
Incorrect: Rutherford Class IIb denotes immediately threatened limbs that are salvageable with immediate revascularization. Sensory loss would involve more than the toes and may be associated with rest pain in the forefoot (not just confined to toes). There would be mild-to-moderate muscle weakness, arterial Doppler signals would typically be inaudible, but there would be audible venous Doppler signals. 
❌ Rutherford Class III :
Incorrect: Rutherford Class III denotes non-viable limbs with severe and permanent nerve deficit. Sensory loss would be profound. Profound muscle weakness with paralysis and possible rigor would be present, and arterial and venous Doppler signals would be inaudible. 
❌ Rutherford Class IV  :
Incorrect: This class does not exist. The Rutherford classification system for acute limb ischemia is from I to III.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following an episode of syncope. The patient’s wife states that he was getting up to do his morning chores when he experienced sudden onset of abdominal pain and loss of consciousness. The patient smokes 2 packs of cigarettes per day and does not have any other significant medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 76/60, pulse is 151/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is awake but ill-appearing. On abdominal examination there is a distended abdomen, and a pulsatile mass is felt on direct palpation of the abdomen. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset of abdominal pain, syncope, a pulsatile mass on examination, and hypotension. This presentation is concerning for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. This patient’s hypotension should be first addressed by administering intravenous fluids before other steps are taken. Then an emergent vascular surgery consult should be called.

An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is defined as aortic dilatation that is greater than 3 cm in diameter. Most AAAs are fusiform, which means they’re spindle-shaped and involve the entire circumference of the aortic wall. AAAs can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. While most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging studies, all AAAs are at risk for expansion and rupture. Symptoms of rupture typically include sudden onset abdomen, back, or flank pain with associated syncope.

The acute management of patients presenting with an abdominal aortic aneurysm involves assessment of stability. Patients with evidence of hypotension, airway compromise, or associated vital sign instability should receive corrective measures before further diagnostics are obtained (e.g. intubation for airway compromise).

Once stabilized, patients with a known history of AAA and a presentation consistent with ruptured AAA should have an emergent vascular surgery consultation. Unstable patients, like this patient, without a known history AAA presenting with history and physical exam suggestive of ruptured AAA should be stabilized and then undergo bedside ultrasound to look for dissection or rupture. Also, an emergent surgical consult should be called.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer normal saline bolus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consult vascular surgery:
Incorrect: This patient presents with features suggesting a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. This patient's hypotension should be addressed first, and then vascular surgery should be called.  
❌ Perform bedside abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm is best diagnosed via bedside ultrasound; however this patient's hypotension should be addressed first.  
❌ Administer esmolol:
Incorrect: Esmolol is indicated in the management of acute aortic dissection, primarily for blood pressure and heart rate control. It is not used in the management of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  
❌ Exploratory laparotomy:
Incorrect: This patient requires immediate fluid resuscitation prior to surgical exploration.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department following an episode of syncope. The patient’s wife states that the patient stood up, complained of severe abdominal pain, and suddenly passed out. The patient has a 30-pack-year smoking history and has not had a healthcare visit in over 10 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 76/56, pulse is 134/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient appears ill with clammy and cool extremities. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass and a diffusely tender abdomen. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis is shown below. IV fluids are started. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

From Researchgate.net

choices.text: Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair
Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds
Admit to ICU for serial abdominal examinations

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of the acute onset of severe abdominal pain followed by syncope. The patient is hemodynamically unstable and is found to have a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The CT scan demonstrates evidence of a large AAA with contrast extravasation indicating rupture. The best next step in management is emergent vascular surgical consultation for repair.

Abdominal aortic aneurysms can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. While most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging studies, all AAAs are at risk for expansion and rupture.

Patients with a AAA rupture typically are unstable and should be treated with stabilizing measures and emergent surgical consultation for open or endovascular repair. Patients with symptomatic AAA with no evidence of rupture on CT should have a surgical consultation. Symptomatic AAAs have a higher risk of complications like rupture or impingement of nearby vascular structures, so they may need surgical intervention. Smaller AAAs ≤ 5.5 cm that are found incidentally may require long-term monitoring by a vascular surgeon and elective repair if they become larger than 5.5 cm.  

Option Analysis

✅ Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds:
Incorrect: Outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds are indicated for patients with asymptomatic aneurysms that are ≤ 5.5 cm in diameter. This patient has clinical and CT findings of a ruptured AAA and requires emergent surgical repair.  
❌ Administer esmolol:
Incorrect: Esmolol is the medication of choice for impulse control in patients with an aortic dissection. This patient has evidence of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and needs emergent surgical repair.  
❌ Administer heparin:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and should undergo emergent vascular repair. Heparin is not indicated and will likely increase bleeding.  
❌ Admit to ICU for serial abdominal examinations:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm and should undergo emergent vascular repair.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for severe tearing chest pain radiating to his back for the past 2 hours and syncope. Past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 93/52 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respirations 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals weak peripheral pulses, and a 4/6 early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard over the left lower sternal border. ECG is significant for sinus tachycardia. IV access is obtained, and intravenous fluids are administered. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography of the chest and abdomen
Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute tearing chest pain radiating to the back and syncope, along with hypotension, tachycardia, weak peripheral pulses, and a diastolic decrescendo murmur heard at the left lower sternal border indicative of aortic regurgitation. These findings are suggestive of an aortic dissection in an unstable patient which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnostic confirmation with a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE).     

An acute aortic dissection in an unstable patient often presents with intense, acute chest pain that feels like a "tear" or "rip" and may radiate to the back. Patients may also experience syncope. Physical examination findings can include tachycardia, hypotension, an audible murmur from aortic regurgitation, and signs of cardiac tamponade if the dissection extends proximally. Other symptoms may arise based on the area of the body with insufficient blood supply. This can result in neurological defects, acute limb ischemia, and anuria due to renal artery involvement.    

In an unstable patient, a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) is the preferred diagnostic tool, as these patients may not be stable enough for other imaging techniques like a CT angiogram (CTA). A TEE may reveal a double lumen, consisting of the true lumen and a false lumen in the dissected portion, and an intraluminal flap between them. Additional findings can include a thrombus in the false lumen and aortic rupture in severe cases. If the ascending aorta is involved signs of cardiac tamponade may be present.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Transesophageal echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CT angiography of the chest and abdomen:
Incorrect: Although CT angiography is highly sensitive and specific for aortic dissection, it is not recommended for patients who are hemodynamically unstable due to the time and risk associated with patient transport. TEE is recommended instead.
❌ Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair:
Incorrect: While emergent surgical repair is indicated for the management of Type A aortic dissections, definitive imaging should be obtained to determine the presence and type of aortic dissection before surgery. 
❌ MR angiography of the chest:
Incorrect: MRA of the chest may be indicated in the evaluation of an acute aortic dissection, but it is not recommended when patients are hemodynamically unstable due to the time and risk associated with patient transport. TEE is recommended instead.
❌ Coronary catheterization:
Incorrect:  Coronary catheterization is indicated in the evaluation and management of an acute STEMI. The presence of tearing pain radiating to the back, the diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation, and the absence of ischemic changes on ECG suggest the diagnosis of aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset severe, sharp, chest pain that radiates to the back and dyspnea. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and a 30-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.2°C (°F), blood pressure is 195/140 mmHg in his right arm and 161/105 mmHg the left arm, pulse is 115/min, respirations 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. Pulmonary examination is significant for bilateral basilar rates. Which of the following murmurs is mostly likely to be heard on cardiac auscultation?

choices.text: Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border
Continuous murmur over the back between the scapula along with decreased lower extremity pulses
Mid-diastolic rumbling murmur with an opening snap
Holosystolic ejection murmur best heard at the apex
A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe, sharp chest pain that radiates to the back, hypertension, and blood pressure discrepancy between the two arms, which is suggestive of an acute aortic dissection. The presence of dyspnea and bilateral basilar crackles on lung examination indicates that the aortic dissection may have extended to the aortic valve, leading to aortic regurgitation which presents with an early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border.    

Acute aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition characterized by the separation of the layers of the aortic wall. This is typically precipitated by an intimal tear which allows blood to enter the media, resulting in the creation of a false lumen. This leads to the obstruction of the true lumen and possibly compromised arterial blood flow to the brain, kidneys, and bowel. Risk factors include uncontrolled hypertension, pre-existing aneurysm, connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, inflammatory conditions such as giant cell arteritis and Takayasu's arteritis, and lifestyle factors such as smoking, and cocaine use.  

The classic clinical presentation often includes the sudden onset of severe, sharp, and tearing chest pain that radiates to the back or abdomen, which can migrate as the dissection extends along the aorta. On physical examination, patients may present with asymmetric blood pressure in the arms, especially if the dissection involves the aortic arch. A diastolic murmur can also be heard if the aortic valve is involved, leading to aortic insufficiency. Additional findings may be present, depending on which part of the body is experiencing inadequate blood supply.  

Option Analysis

✅ Early diastolic decrescendo murmur best heard at the left lower sternal border:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Continuous murmur over the back between the scapula along with decreased lower extremity pulses:
Incorrect: This murmur is heard in patients with coarctation of the aorta, which presents earlier in life and with chronic symptoms. The acute onset of severe, sharp, chest pain and the presence of a significant blood pressure discrepancy in the arms is more indicative of an aortic dissection which can lead to aortic regurgitation.
❌ Mid-diastolic rumbling murmur with an opening snap:
Incorrect: This heart murmur indicates mitral stenosis which, worldwide, is most commonly caused by rheumatic fever.
❌ Holosystolic ejection murmur best heard at the apex:
Incorrect: This heart murmur is indicative of a mitral regurgitation, which can cause shortness of breath. However, the presence of acute, severe, sharp, chest pain that radiates to the back and the discrepancy in blood pressures between the arms, is consistent with an acute aortic dissection, which can lead to aortic regurgitation.
❌ A crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the 2nd right intercostal space:
Incorrect: This heart murmur is indicative of aortic stenosis, which can cause chest pain and dyspnea. This patient’s chest pain radiates to the back and the discrepancy in blood pressure between the arms is consistent with an acute aortic dissection, which can lead to aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to severe chest pain radiating to her back for 1 hour.
