Past medical history is significant for uncontrolled hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 36.3°C (°F), blood pressure is 210/120 mmHg in both arms, pulse is 108/min, respirations 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears in pain. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Chest radiograph reveals a widened mediastinum. CT angiogram of the chest demonstrates a double lumen separated by an intraluminal flap in the aorta extending from the left subclavian artery to the abdominal aorta. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and smoking presents with severe chest pain radiating to the back, severely elevated blood pressure, and a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray. This clinical presentation is suggestive of an acute aortic dissection which is confirmed by CT angiography. The presence of an intraluminal dissection flap and double lumen in the descending aorta is consistent with the diagnosis of a type B aortic dissection, which can be managed with intravenous blood pressure control with IV labetalol if there are no complicating features.    

The treatment approach for aortic dissection depends on its classification and the patient's condition. For Stanford type A dissections, which involve the ascending aorta, emergent surgical intervention is necessary due to the high risk of aortic rupture, cardiac tamponade, and severe aortic insufficiency. For Stanford type B dissections, which involve the descending aorta, management is based on the presence or absence of complications. Uncomplicated cases are usually managed medically with aggressive blood pressure control using IV beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers. The aim is to reduce the strain on the aortic wall and prevent further expansion of the dissection. If complications arise such as persistent pain, rapid aortic expansion, impending rupture, or signs of end-organ ischemia, urgent surgical consultation should be called to assess the need for open repair or endovascular repair with graft placement to minimize the risk of rupture.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer intravenous labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emergent surgical consultation for surgical repair:
Incorrect: Emergent surgical repair is required for type A aortic dissections, which involve the ascending aorta. This patient has a type B dissection, which can initially be managed medically with aggressive blood pressure control if there are no complications.
❌ Oral diltiazem:
Incorrect: Oral antihypertensives such as diltiazem, a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker, can be used for blood pressure control in stable chronic hypertension. In acute settings, intravenous antihypertensives like labetalol are preferred.
❌  Intravenous nitroglycerin:
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin can be used to control blood pressure; however, it can cause reflex tachycardia which may worsen an aortic dissection. It should be avoided in cases of suspected aortic dissection.
❌  Intravenous heparin:
Incorrect:  IV heparin is an anticoagulant indicated in the management of acute coronary syndromes and pulmonary embolisms. It is contraindicated in the management of acute aortic dissection due to the risk of bleeding and extension of the dissection.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the emergency department for bilateral leg pain and a lesion on the right foot. The patient is a retired school teacher and enjoys gardening in his spare time. Recently, he has had to stop his gardening every few minutes and rest due to intermittent leg pain and cramping. Until three weeks ago, the pain was relieved by resting. However, now it occurs even when sitting down and resting, and he also has associated bilateral foot pain. Two weeks ago, he noted a lesion on his right toe that has remained stable. There is no associated cough, dyspnea, orthopnea, or chest pain. The patient has hypertension that is well controlled with enalapril. He has smoked cigarettes for 10 years and is currently trying to quit. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, blood pressure is 124/86 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98% on room air. On physical examination, there is a nicotine patch on the patient’s right shoulder. The lower extremities are cool and hairless bilaterally. There are no palpable distal pulses. There is a solitary ulcer with punched-out edges and a dry base on the big right toe that is painful to touch. Bilateral ankle-brachial index is 0.7. Based on this patient’s history and findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of smoking and hypertension and presents with progressive claudication of the lower extremities. The pain now occurs at rest and is present in the feet, and the patient has a foot ulcer that has been present for 2 weeks. These findings, in combination with the abnormal ankle-brachial index (ABI) < 0.9 are consistent with severe peripheral arterial disease (PAD) which is also known as chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI).  

CLTI is a severe form of PAD that presents with rest pain in the feet, non-healing ulcers in the feet, or tissue necrosis(gangrene) lasting > 2 weeks. This patient has had PAD that has progressed to severe PAD or CLTI. Additional studies are often required to assess these patients and may include doppler ultrasound or CTA of the lower extremities to determine disease severity and optimal management.    

Severe CLTI can lead to limb-threatening disease that may require amputation. Signs of advanced CLTI include ABI < 0.4, and low or absent pedal flow on duplex ultrasonography.    

Treatment of CLTI consists of risk management with smoking cessation, antiplatelet therapy, pain management and referral to wound care. Revascularization or debridement via surgery may be needed in severe cases (e.g., infection, severe necrosis, gangrene).   

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic limb-threatening ischemia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Venous thrombosis:
Incorrect: Patients with venous thrombosis typically present with unilateral leg swelling and pain (exacerbated by walking), along with redness and warmth over the affected area. This patient’s progressive claudication, abnormal ABI and likely arterial ulcer point towards chronic limb-threatening ischemia or PAD.
❌ Wet gangrene:
Incorrect: Wet gangrene results from a bacterial infection of an open ulcer and presents with drainage from the wound with surrounding erythema. This patient has an ulcer with punched-out edges and a dry base that is suggestive of arterial disease.
❌ Dry gangrene:
Incorrect: Dry gangrene appears as painless mummified necrotic tissue. This patient has pain at the site of the lesion with punched-out edges and a dry base. There is no evidence of dry gangrene.
❌ Neuropathic ulcer:
Incorrect: Neuropathic ulcers can result from inadequately controlled diabetes mellitus and lack of sensation in the lower extremities. Neuropathic foot ulcers typically develop on pressure points like the pedal prominences and are painless due to the lack of sensation. This patient does not have diabetes or other disorders that cause neuropathy.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the left leg. The pain began about two hours ago and is non-radiating. Nothing has made the pain better or worse. He has never experienced this type of pain before. His past medical history is significant for atrial fibrillation for which he takes rivaroxaban and metoprolol. The patient lost his job and insurance recently, which has made affording his medications difficult. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 114/min and irregular, respiratory rate 14/min, and blood pressure 136/80. A focused vascular exam of the left leg reveals non-palpable distal pulses and absent arterial doppler signals but present venous doppler signals. The left foot and ankle demonstrate decreased strength, and there is decreased sensation to the ankle. CT angiography is obtained and shows an occluded left distal superficial femoral artery without runoff. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with severe pain in the left leg in the setting of an occluded distal superficial femoral artery (SFA) as diagnosed on CT angiogram (CTA). Given that the patient has not been able to afford medications for his atrial fibrillation, he likely had an embolus to the distal SFA. In the presence of motor and sensory deficits, this patient has an immediately threatened limb (Rutherford Class IIB). For most patients with an immediately threatened extremity, surgical revascularization with open embolectomy is the most appropriate initial treatment.        

For this patient, once an immediately threatened limb is suspected from history and exam, the patient should be started on IV heparin infusion immediately, and a CTA of the extremity should be ordered for surgical planning. An arterial occlusion causing an immediately threatened limb is a surgical emergency requiring revascularization, usually within six hours. The surgical team should be consulted for immediate revascularization.        

An open embolectomy is the surgical treatment of choice. One of the main advantages of an open embolectomy is that blood flow is generally restored very quickly. However, if comorbidities increase the risk for general anesthesia, a femoral cutdown and embolectomy can be performed under regional or local anesthesia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Femoral cutdown and embolectomy :
Incorrect: Open embolectomy, which quickly restores blood flow to the affected limb, is the treatment of choice for an immediately threatened limb. If this patient had comorbidities that prevented the use of general anesthesia, then a femoral cutdown with embolectomy could be considered. 
❌ Anticoagulation :
Incorrect: This patient requires systemic anticoagulation to prevent additional clot formation; however, anticoagulation will not dissolve the clot that is already present in the leg. This patient requires open embolectomy to remove the clot. 
✅ Open embolectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thrombolysis  :
Incorrect: Patients with an immediately threatened limb are generally not good candidates for thrombolysis. Although pharmacologic thrombolysis may successfully dissolve the embolus, the time required is usually too long for it to be an acceptable alternative to surgery with open embolectomy.  
❌ Four compartment fasciotomy  :
Incorrect: Depending upon the duration and severity of the ischemia, a fasciotomy may be required to prevent the development of compartment syndrome following reperfusion. However, fasciotomy does not treat acute limb ischemia, and open embolectomy to establish reperfusion is necessary.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of left flank pain that woke the patient up abruptly from sleep. Also he saw blood in his urine with his first urination of the day. The patient has a past medical history of nephrolithiasis, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and a 20-pack-year smoking history. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable and diaphoretic. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/66, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical exam reveals left costovertebral angle tenderness, and a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpated. Urinalysis shows hematuria. A bedside ultrasound shows an abdominal aortic aneurysm that is 3.5 cm in diameter as demonstrated below. A CT of the abdomen and pelvis without contrast demonstrates a 5 mm obstructing left kidney stone. Which of the following is the best management for the abdominal aneurysm finding?
 

From Radiopea

choices.text: Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds
Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair
Admit to the ICU for serial ultrasound examinations

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of acute onset left flank pain and hematuria and is found to have a left kidney stone on CT. He has an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Given that the aneurysm diameter is less than 5.5 cm, it is at low risk for rupture. The patient has an alternative etiology to explain his symptoms. Therefore he has an asymptomatic AAA that is less than 5.5 cm The best management is to follow him with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds.

An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is defined as aortic dilatation greater than 3 cm in diameter. Most AAAs are fusiform, which means they’re spindle-shaped and involve the entire circumference of the aortic wall. AAAs can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. While most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging studies, all AAAs are at risk for expansion and rupture.

Management of AAA is dependent on patient stability. Patients that are unstable, meaning those with evidence of hypotension, altered mental status, airway compromise, and rupture should have emergent surgical consultation for open or endovascular repair. Stable patients with evidence of a symptomatic AAA should receive surgical consultation for possible surgical or endovascular repair. Patients who are found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm incidentally that is ≤ 5.5 cm, should be monitored in the outpatient setting with serial abdominal ultrasounds.

Option Analysis

✅ Follow with outpatient serial abdominal ultrasounds:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Consult vascular surgery for emergent repair:
Incorrect:  This patient presents for evaluation of left flank pain and hematuria that is likely secondary to nephrolithiasis. The patient is incidentally found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm without evidence of rupture. Given the size of this aneurysm, the patient should be monitored as an outpatient with serial ultrasounds.  
❌ Administer esmolol:
Incorrect:  Esmolol is used in the treatment of aortic dissection. This patient has evidence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm that is incidentally found and is not likely contributing to this patient’s symptoms, therefore he does not need acute management for it.  
❌ Admit to the ICU for serial ultrasound examinations:
Incorrect: This patient presents for evaluation of left flank pain and hematuria, which is likely secondary to nephrolithiasis. The patient is incidentally found to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm without evidence of rupture. Given the size of the aneurysm, he should be monitored as an outpatient with serial ultrasounds and does not need acute monitoring or treatment for it.  
❌ Administer sodium nitroprusside:
Incorrect: Sodium nitroprusside Is an alternative agent for impulse control in patients with aortic dissections. This patient has evidence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm that is incidentally noted, not ruptured, and 3.5 cm in diameter. It is not likely contributing to his current symptoms and does not need acute management.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for routine examination. He is in his usual state of health. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia and takes hydrochlorothiazide, rosuvastatin, and aspirin. He exercises regularly and follows a Mediterranean diet. He does not smoke cigarettes. He drinks 1 glass of red wine daily. His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. Temperature is 36.4 °C (97.5 °F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 123/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. BMI is 23 kg/m2. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Carotid artery upstroke is normal. Abdominal examination is normal. Fasting cholesterol levels are obtained and are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Total cholesterol
158 mg/dL  
LDL
90 mg/dL
HDL
46 mg/dL
Triglycerides
110 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has 3 risk factors that place him at high-risk for carotid artery disease: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and family history of atherosclerosis before the age of 60 years. Therefore, he should be referred for a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.

Society guidelines for screening asymptomatic patients for carotid artery disease differ. Screening recommendations discussed here are based on guidelines from the American College of Cardiology Foundation/American Heart Association Task Force on Practice Guidelines. Screening for carotid artery disease in asymptomatic patients is based on personal and family history, and patients who are at high risk for carotid artery disease should undergo a carotid artery duplex ultrasound. Patients who have a history of atherosclerotic disease, (peripheral arterial disease or coronary artery disease), are considered high-risk for carotid artery stenosis. In addition, patients who have 2 or more of the following are also at high-risk for carotid artery stenosis: hypertension, hyperlipidemia, tobacco use, family history of atherosclerosis diagnosed before age 60, and a family history of ischemic stroke.  

Option Analysis

✅ Refer for carotid duplex ultrasound:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increase rosuvastatin dose:
Incorrect: This patient’s cholesterol levels are at target and rosuvastatin does not need to be increased. However, this patient is at high risk for carotid artery disease and should have a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.  
❌ Add lisinopril:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is at target levels and additional medication, such as lisinopril, is not necessary. However, this patient is at high risk for carotid artery disease and should have a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.  
❌ Refer for cardiac stress test:
Incorrect: A cardiac stress test is not recommended for asymptomatic patients. However, this patient is at high risk for carotid artery disease and should have a carotid artery duplex ultrasound.  
❌ Order a calcium CT score:
Incorrect: A calcium CT score is not necessary for this patient since it is used to identify patients who should be treated with statin therapy, and this patient is already on rosuvastatin.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician’s office with concerns about her stroke risk because her older sister had a stroke last month. She feels well without neurologic or cardiac symptoms. She had coronary artery bypass grafting after a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. She takes lovastatin and aspirin. She exercises regularly. She does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. Temperature is 36.4 °C (97.5 °F), pulse is 75/min, blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg, and respirations are 14/min. Carotid artery upstroke is normal bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Abdominal examination is normal. Cholesterol levels are at target. There is no peripheral edema. Carotid duplex ultrasound shows 60% stenosis of the right carotid artery with no ulcerations. There is no stenosis in the left carotid artery. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has 60% stenosis of the right carotid artery without ulcerations, and therefore she should be monitored with annual carotid duplex examinations to determine if there is disease progression.

All patients with carotid artery stenosis should be counseled about lifestyle changes including a healthy diet, smoking cessation, weight reduction, and regular exercise. They should be started on intensive medical therapy with statins, antiplatelet agents like aspirin, and medication for high blood pressure and glycemic control if necessary.

Patients with carotid artery stenosis <50% should be offered annual carotid artery duplex ultrasound if they have multiple risk factors. All patients with stenosis 50-69%, should be monitored with annual carotid artery duplex ultrasound. Patients who have carotid stenosis >70% and those who have worrisome features on the ultrasound, such as plaque ulcerations, should be referred for surgical treatment for revascularization which can include stenting and endarterectomy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Annual carotid duplex examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Add antihypertensive medication:
Incorrect: This patient’s blood pressure is at target level and an antihypertensive does not need to be added.  
❌ Endarterectomy:
Incorrect: Endarterectomy is not recommended unless stenosis of >70% or worrisome features such as plaque ulcerations are seen on carotid duplex exam.  
❌ Increase lovastatin:
Incorrect: The lovastatin dose should be based on the patient’s cholesterol levels which are currently at target.  
❌ Carotid stenting:
Incorrect: Carotid stenting is not recommended unless stenosis of >70% or worrisome features such as plaque ulcerations are seen on carotid duplex exam.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman comes to the office because of a three-month history of right lower extremity pain and burning. Initially, the pain occurred only while walking; however, now, the pain is constant and throbbing at rest. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and aspirin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. Temperature is 37.1℃ (98.8℉), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates a lack of hair and decreased skin temperature over the right foot. The right pedal pulse is not palpable. A diagnosis of peripheral vascular disease is established, and after further evaluations the patient is scheduled for femoropopliteal bypass surgery. The vascular surgeon prepares to harvest the longest vein in the body to use for the procedure. This vein can be accessed via which of the following anatomic sites?
questions.solution:
The great saphenous vein is the longest vein in the body and spans the leg length. It originates at the medial aspect of the foot, where it courses anterior to the medial malleolus and travels superiorly via the medial side of the leg to just inferior to the pubic tubercle. There, it joins the femoral vein through the cribriform fascia of the saphenous opening. Both the great and the lesser saphenous vein can be used for bypass grafting, with the great saphenous vein being the more popular choice due to its ease of access because of its superficial position and its vascular wall rich in muscular and elastic fibers.  

The great saphenous vein is commonly used in coronary artery bypass grafting and peripheral arterial bypassgrafting. The two most common and significant complications arising from saphenous vein grafting include thrombosis and atherosclerosis, ultimately leading to graft failure. Saphenous nerve injury can occur during harvesting and presents with pain or numbness along the medial border of the foot.   

Option Analysis

❌ Femoral triangle:
Incorrect: The great saphenous vein terminates deep in the femoral triangle where it joins the femoral vein. The depth of the vein at this location and its proximity to nearby vascular structures precludes harvesting at this site.
✅ Medial thigh:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lateral aspect of the foot:
Incorrect: The small saphenous vein is located at the lateral aspect of the foot, where it courses posteriorly, draining into the popliteal vein. The small saphenous vein is not typically utilized for peripheral artery bypass grafting.
❌ Mid-inguinal point:
Incorrect: The mid-inguinal point is found halfway between the pubic symphysis and anterior superior iliac spine and serves as a landmark to locate the femoral artery. It can be accessed for diagnostic or therapeutic purposes (e.g. catheter insertion) but not for bypass grafting.
❌ Superior to the inguinal ligament:
Incorrect: The deep circumflex iliac vessels course parallel and just superior to the inguinal ligament. The deep circumflex iliac vessels are not typically utilized for peripheral artery bypass grafting.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman presents to the trauma bay after a motor vehicle collision. The patient veered off the road to avoid an animal and hit a tree. Airbags deployed, and part of a branch went through the windshield, impaling the patient in the neck. Upon arrival to the emergency department, the primary survey is intact. Temperature is 36 °C (98 °F), heart rate is 124, blood pressure is 136/72, and respiratory rate 14. Secondary survey reveals a branch (diameter 1.5 cm) entering and exiting the left neck in Zone 2, as well as left knee tenderness. All distal pulses are palpable. CT-A of the head, neck and chest shows a blush indicating potential injury near the left carotid artery but is otherwise negative. Given the concern for laryngotracheal and pharyngoesophageal injuries, a triple endoscopy is performed and is negative. The patient remains hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Perform external compression of the neck for 15 minutes

questions.solution:
This patient presents to the trauma bay with a stable penetrating neck injury (PNI). Secondary survey is notable for a branch impaling Zone 2 of the neck. Triple endoscopy is negative, ruling out laryngotracheal and pharyngoesophageal injuries; however, CT-A shows a blush near the left carotid artery, suggesting potential vascular injury. Therefore, this patient should have a vascular surgery consultation to determine the need for open or endovascular repair of the carotid artery.        

In patients with Zone 2 or 3 injuries, vascular surgery should be consulted. However, if a zone I vascular injury is suspected, a trauma or thoracic surgeon may be needed and should be consulted. A range of surgical and interventional options exist for the management of vascular injuries, including embolization, ligation, stent placement, surgical repair, and revascularization. Early revascularization offers the best chance for successful outcomes when managing injuries to the carotid artery.        

If the CTA had shown a pneumomediastinum, an aerodigestive tract injury would be suspected. If the esophagram showed contrast extravasation, but the flexible bronchoscopy was negative, it would indicate an upper esophageal injury and/or pharyngeal injury. Urgent surgical intervention with repair and wide drainage would be the treatment of choice. On the other hand, if the esophagram was negative, but the flexible bronchoscopy showed evidence of injury to the airway, an airway injury would be diagnosed and managed with operative repair.   

Option Analysis

❌ Admit for observation :
Incorrect: In patients with a suspected vascular injury, managing the injury is the most appropriate next step. While observation might ultimately be the final recommendation, this plan should be made based on evaluation from a vascular surgeon.  
❌ Repeat CT-A in 4 hours :
Incorrect: Initial CT-A has shown a potential vascular injury of the left carotid artery. A repeat CT is unnecessary. This patient should have an evaluation by a vascular surgeon.  
✅ Consult vascular surgery  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform external compression of the neck for 15 minutes :
Incorrect: For superficial bleeding due to vessels in the subcutaneous space, external compression is effective at achieving hemostasis. However, deeper vessels, including the carotid arteries, require operative repair to achieve hemostasis. A vascular surgery consult is necessary to determine the need for open or endovascular repair. 
❌ Consult neurology for stroke prevention :
Incorrect: Given the suspected injury to the carotid artery, this patient is at higher risk for a stroke. While neurology can be consulted to help optimize stroke prevention medications, the next step in management should be a vascular surgery consult for possible open or endovascular repair.

questions.text: A 78-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a “cold” left leg. The patient woke up this morning and went to put on socks when he noticed that his left leg was cool to touch. He normally has pain in the leg that is worse at night and exacerbated by walking, but his leg has never felt cool. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus. The patient has an allergy to penicillin as well as to iodinated contrast. Temperature is 37.3ºC (99.1ºF), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min and blood pressure is 139/84 mmHg. On physical exam, the left leg is cool and pale, and he is unable to plantar- or dorsiflex the left foot. Motor strength is diminished with left knee flexion and extension. Sensation is absent up to the mid calf. There are non-palpable pulses in the distal left leg and absent venous/arterial doppler signals. Which of the following suspected diagnosis and associated imaging modality is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with pallor, pulselessness, poikilothermia, paresthesia, and paralysis of the left leg which is concerning for severe acute limb ischemia. Given the absence of both venous and arterial doppler signals, he likely has a non-viable limb. This patient has an iodinated contrast allergy; therefore, iodinated contrast should be avoided and CT angiogram cannot be used to confirm the diagnosis. Instead, duplex arterial ultrasound (doppler ultrasound) should be used to confirm the diagnosis and determine the level of occlusion of the nonviable limb.         

Whenever feasible, CT angiography should be obtained in patients with suspected limb ischemia because it provides valuable information about the location of embolic debris and the amount and location of baseline atherosclerotic plaque burden. It can also detect aneurysmal disease. Even in the setting of acute limb ischemia, CT angiography can usually be performed quickly while preparing the patient for intervention. The information gained from CTA may also be helpful for deciding whether to pursue open surgery or catheter-based intervention as well as determining the specifics of the chosen approach.        

Magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) has limitations when evaluating acute embolic disease, one of which is the additional time needed to complete the study. Calcium is poorly visualized, and the spatial resolution may also be limited for evaluating ulcerative plaques or irregular atheroma (but this can vary by available equipment and protocols). If IV contrast is contraindicated as in the patient in this vignette, then duplex arterial ultrasound can be used to visualize the occlusion and evaluate the affected vasculature. It can show loss of flow in the artery and loss of the associated Doppler waveform.   

Option Analysis

❌ Non-viable limb; MR angiography :
Incorrect: Given that this patient’s leg exhibits pallor, paresthesia, paralysis, poikilothermia, and pulselessness, he has a non-viable limb. MRA is an alternative vascular imaging modality that provides clear images, but it requires access and time that this patient does not have.  
❌ Non-viable limb; CT angiography :
Incorrect: A CTA would be the diagnostic imaging modality of choice when evaluating acute limb ischemia. However, given this patient’s allergy to iodinated contrast, contrast should be avoided.  
✅ Non-viable limb; Doppler ultrasound :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Threatened limb; Doppler ultrasound :
Incorrect: This patient has 5 out of the 6 “P’s” of acute limb ischemia. Therefore, the most appropriate diagnosis is a non-viable limb, not a threatened limb.  
❌ Threatened limb; carbon dioxide angiogram :
Incorrect: This patient has 5 out of the 6 “P’s” of acute limb ischemia. Therefore, the most appropriate diagnosis is a non-viable limb, not a threatened limb. CT angiogram cannot be performed since it utilizes contrast, which is contraindicated in this patient. There are centers that utilize carbon dioxide angiograms, but these are not standard practice.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation after falling down three flights of stairs. The patient currently has lower abdominal pain. He has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes and takes hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, and metformin daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 148/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On arrival, the patient can state his name and has normal breathing sounds bilaterally. Glasgow coma scale (GCS) is 15. There is a cervical collar in place, supplemental oxygen is applied, access is established, and intravenous fluids are administered. Secondary survey reveals ecchymosis over the left lower abdomen. Extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) and X-ray of the chest and abdomen are negative. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis demonstrates a grade 1 splenic laceration without evidence of other traumatic injury. The patient continues to require intravenous fluids despite infusion of multiple liters of lactated ringer. Tertiary survey reveals repeat blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg and repeat abdominal and vascular exam reveals a pulsatile mass over the lower abdomen. The patient has 2+ pulses in the upper extremities, and 1+ pulses in the bilateral lower extremities. Which of the following findings is most likely to be discovered in further imaging studies?
questions.solution:
This 64-year-old patient presents following a significant fall with blunt abdominal trauma. The patient is stable and the only finding on imaging is a grade 1 splenic laceration. However, the patient requires continued resuscitation with intravenous fluids. The tertiary survey reveals low bp, a pulsatile abdominal mass and diminished lower extremity pulses bilaterally, suggesting blunt aortic injury. Repeat CT is most likely to show an aortic mural hematoma.  There may have been a missed injury to the abdominal aorta. Reviewing all imaging studies is part of the tertiary survey along with ordering additional imaging.

Tertiary examination should be performed on all trauma patients because it decreases the frequency of missed iոjuries. It is typically performed within 24 hours of a trauma patient being admitted to the hospital. A tertiary survey is a final check to identify any injuries that may have been missed during the primary and secondary surveys and to assess for any changes. It involves repeating the secondary survey, reviewing all imaging and laboratory data, and performing additional targeted studies.

A missed intra-abdominal inϳսrу should be suspected in patients with blunt or penetrating trauma who have evidence of ongoing acidosis, persistent tachycardia, the need for ongoing fluid resuscitation or trаոѕfսѕiоոs, abdominal sepsis, or systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS). Most missed injuries are not life-threatening and involve an injury of the extremities missed on primary or secondary survey.

Option Analysis

✅ Aortic mural hematoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Contrast extravasation from mesenteric vessels:
Incorrect: Contrast extravasation from mesenteric vessels would be expected in a patient with mesenteric injury. This patient presents with a pulsatile abdominal mass and diminished pulses in the lower extremities, suggesting an abdominal aortic injury.  
❌ Contrast extravasation about the spleen:
Incorrect: Splenic injury commonly occurs following blunt abdominal trauma. While this patient has a splenic injury, patients with grade 1 splenic injury are typically stable and managed conservatively. This patient also has a pulsatile abdominal mass and diminished pulses in the lower extremities suggesting an abdominal aortic injury.
❌ Pelvic hematoma:
Incorrect: Pelvic hematoma can often form after pelvic fracture due to the shearing forces on nearby blood vessels. CT does not show pelvic fracture. This patient has a pulsatile abdominal mass and diminished pulses in the lower extremities suggesting an abdominal aortic injury.
❌ Bladder rupture :
Incorrect: A bladder rupture would most likely present with free fluid on eFAST and findings on CT imaging. This patient’s extended focused assessment with sonography in trauma (eFAST) was negative. And CT did not show bladder rupture.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a syncopal episode that occurred after the acute onset of sudden and severe low back and groin pain. The patient was in his usual state of health before this episode. He has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension, diabetes type 2, and a 30-pack-year smoking history. The patient denies dysuria, hematuria, polyuria or incontinence. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 96/56 mmHg, pulse is 134/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals a pale and ill-appearing man. Genitourinary examination demonstrates normal appearing external genitalia. Back examination is unremarkable. Which of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be found on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an episode of sudden and severe low back and groin pain followed by syncope. He is hypotensive and ill-appearing. Together these clinical findings are concerning for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. One of the hallmark clinical findings is the presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass.

An abdominal aortic aneurysm, or AAA, is defined as aortic dilatation greater than 3 cm in diameter. Most AAAs are fusiform, which means they’re spindle-shaped and involve the entire circumference of the aortic wall. AAA can be symptomatic or asymptomatic. While most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally on imaging studies, all AAAs are at risk for expansion and rupture.

Most abdominal aortic aneurysms are silent, meaning, they are discovered incidentally on imaging without any associated symptoms or clinical findings. Symptomatic patients typically present in the setting of rupture or peri-rupture and present with sudden onset abdominal, back, or flank pain with or without groin pain and with associated syncope. Risk factors associated with AAA include those associated with atherosclerotic disease, including hypertension, diabetes, and smoking history. Patients may also have a history of connective tissue disease or a familial history of aneurysm.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pulsatile abdominal mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Migratory thrombophlebitis:
Incorrect: Migratory thrombophlebitis is also known as Courvasiers’ sign, and it is associated with abdominal malignancies—most notably pancreatic adenocarcinoma. This patient has had no prior epigastric pain, nausea, malaise, or unintentional weight loss which would be consistent with pancreatic cancer.  
❌ Diminished radial pulse:
Incorrect: A diminished radial pulse can be seen with a thoracic aortic aneurysm or dissection. Pulse deficits of the lower extremities may be encountered in patients like this one with an abdominal aneurysm or dissection.  
❌ Absent cremasteric reflex:
Incorrect: This finding is often observed in patients with testicular torsion. This patient has a normal genito-urinary exam.  
❌ Positive straight leg raise:
Incorrect: A positive straight leg raise is indicative of sciatica, not an abdominal aortic aneurysm which is the likely diagnosis in this patient.
